quotes:
• "The problem with the program, housing advocates say, is rooted in how CMHC determines affordability."
  • "Even the median renter household in Ottawa – that includes two incomes – only makes $66,300 annually, according to the most recent data from Statistics Canada. This puts the SoHo’s two-bedroom, starting at $2,320 a month, out of reasonable reach as well."
  • "What it considers “affordable” is out of whack with reality, said Steve Pomeroy, who runs his own housing policy research company, Focus Consulting Inc., and has analyzed the ACLP extensively."
  • "Though, even if CMHC linked project financing to a lower affordable rent, developers say they wouldn’t be able to build because the cost of construction is prohibitive."
  • "“Any supply is good,” Mr. Pomeroy said. “But if you’re pretending that it’s affordable, it’s not. That’s just deceitful.” It’s all the more problematic, Mr. Pomeroy said, that the program is the largest in the government’s national housing strategy, which is supposed to prioritize housing for “those in the greatest need.”"
  • "In Winnipeg, four projects had higher average affordable rents than average market rent in the city. "
  • "In some cities, CMHC’s affordability measure actually allows rents higher than what landlords could even expect to charge."
  • "In fact, the ACLP defines an “affordable rent” that is so high that most renters would have to double their income to make their monthly payments. "
  • "Its president, Bruce Greenberg, said the tower would not have been feasible with stricter affordability measures under the current program – and, given the rising costs of construction, could not be built again today under those same rules."
summary:
Summary

The Canada Mortgage and Housing Corp.'s (CMHC) $86-million loan to SoHo Italia under the Apartment Construction Loan Program (ACLP) aimed to provide affordable housing, yet the rents exceed what typical renters can afford. The program's affordability criteria, a CMHC statistic based on median household income, has been criticized for being disconnected from the reality of renter incomes. A Globe and Mail analysis found that 87 of 177 projects approved through the ACLP had average affordable rents unaffordable for typical renter households. With construction costs high, developers argue they couldn't build at lower rents, while critics say the program's definition of affordability is misleading.

Key Points

  • SoHo Italia rental project specifics:
    • Loan Amount: $86 million
    • Number of Units: 250 units
    • median household income for an individual renter in Ottawa: $41,800
      • rent for a SoHo apartment "more than half of a typical renter's income"
  • Problem with program is in how CMHC determines affordability:
    • project allocation "if at least 20% of new units can be rented for less than 30 per cent of median household income of all families in the particular city where they are being built"
    • affordability statistic:
      • median household income
        • encompasses renters and homeowners:
        • median household income for all families (renters and owners): $98,690
        • median household income for household that rents: $57,900
      • "homeowners outnumber renters and have incomes that are nearly twice as high"
    • CMHC when asked why they don't use the median income of renters stat:
      • "a spokesperson for the agency emphasized the program’s impact on Canada’s housing supply shortage, saying the program has spurred construction of apartments that wouldn’t otherwise have been created"
  • Apartment Construction Loan Program (ACLP):
    • Total Investment in ACLP: $55 billion
    • Number of Rental Units Financed by ACLP: 31,840 rental units (CMHC)
      • only represent 7% of all new rentals started in the same period
    • "half of the projects approved for loans had average affordable rents that are not affordable to the typical household that rents rather than owns" - The Globe analysis based on the national median renter household income and Access to Information Act requests
      • only 11 are affordable for single-income renter households
      • minimum wage workers can covert the rent in only 9 projects
    • EX:
      • "highest avg. affordable rents" is a 270 unit Winnipeg project for seniors
      • avg 'affordable rents' listed on CMHC documents as $2,018 per month
      • avg. market rent for a 2 bedroom in a purpose-built rental building (CMHC rental report) at $1,427
      • 4 projects in Winnipeg have similar cases
      • Number of Occupations Out of Reach for ACLP Affordability
        • 270 occupations
    • Gov wording for the program changed over the years:
      • "affordability" has largely disappeared from the ACLP press releases
  • Developer side of the issue:
    • criticism overlooks an essential consideration, "none of them would have built apartments for rents at that price because their profit margins would be too small or non-existent."
title: Ottawa is funding affordable rental projects that aren’t actually affordable

summary:
Summary

The Canadian government plans to include rent payments in credit scores, potentially aiding millions in building credit history. The 2024 budget includes renter initiatives like a $15-million tenant protection fund and a renters' bill of rights. Equifax supports the move, noting a 20% increase in renter households from 2011 to 2021. However, challenges exist in verifying payments from numerous landlords, especially small ones. Tenant advocates warn of risks to low-income renters and the need for safeguards. Approximately 20% of renter households could already be using similar services like FrontLobby.

Facts

  • Renter households increase
    • 20% (from 4.1 million to 5 million units)
  • Tenant protection fund
    • $15 million
  • FrontLobby service usage
    • 20% of renter households
title: Ottawa’s plan to count rent payments toward credit scores needs safeguards, tenant advocates say

Summary

CSIS Director David Vigneault challenged claims by Prime Minister Trudeau and aides that they were not fully briefed on Chinese interference in the 2019 and 2021 elections. Vigneault testified at the Foreign Interference Commission, asserting that he had informed the government about clandestine activities, although they did not alter election outcomes. Trudeau had questioned the reliability of CSIS intelligence, while his aide Jeremy Broadhurst denied receiving specific warnings. Vigneault defended CSIS's professionalism and the accuracy of their assessments.

Key Points

  • CSIS Intelligence on Chinese Election Meddling
    • 2019 and 2021 federal elections
    • Described as "clandestine and deceptive"
  • Government's Knowledge
    • Claims of not being fully informed
  • Trudeau's Testimony
    • Questioned CSIS intelligence reliability
  • Briefing Notes
    • Content not fully relayed to Trudeau's aides
  • Vigneault's Defense of CSIS
    • Asserted repeated communication of interference
    • Defended intelligence work and professionalism
title: CSIS director pushes back on notion he did not fully brief Liberals on Chinese interference

```html
Summary

Canada has imposed sanctions on 21 individuals under the Special Economic Measures (Belarus) Regulations due to ongoing human rights violations following Belarus's 2020 presidential election, deemed fraudulent by international observers. These sanctions coincide with the visit of Belarusian opposition leader Sviatlana Tsikhanouskaya to Ottawa. The EU has also sanctioned these individuals. Canada reaffirms its commitment to Belarusian rights and ending state-sponsored violence.
```

```html
Summary

The Canadian government's Budget 2024 includes a new Secondary Suite Loan Program offering up to $40,000 in low-interest loans to homeowners for adding rental units. This initiative follows zoning reforms in major cities, facilitated by Housing Accelerator Fund agreements, to increase housing density. Budget 2024 also plans to revise mortgage insurance rules to support home densification. These measures aim to expand affordable housing, provide income for seniors, and accommodate families with disabled members.

Facts
```

title: Government making it easier for homeowners to add additional suites to their homes

In March, purpose-built rental apartment rents in Canada increased by 12.7%, reaching an average of $2,117, while condominium rents rose by 3.9%, averaging $2,321. Overall, rents went up by 8.8% to $2,181. Vancouver and Toronto saw average rent declines to $2,993 and $2,782, respectively, yet remained the most expensive cities. Summary

Canada's culture and sport sectors' real GDP fell by 0.8% in Q4, marking a second consecutive quarterly decline, while nominal GDP rose by 0.5% due to price increases. Jobs in these sectors dropped by 0.5% to 806,394. The audio-visual and interactive media domain saw a 1.0% decline in Q4, continuing from a 3.1% fall in Q3, largely due to the Hollywood actors' strike. Over 2023, nominal GDP for culture and sport sectors grew by 5.5%, real GDP by 1.8%, and jobs by 1.5%. Heritage and libraries, and live performance domains showed strong growth, while the audio-visual and interactive media domain lagged.

quotes: "Research to Insights: Social, Economic, and Health Perspectives on Climate Change" - " "Daily mortality risk was 2% to 8% higher than average during extreme heat events from 2000 to 2020 for 12 large Canadian cities" - " "The percentage of people with household air conditioning in 2017 varied by region, ranging from 32% in British Columbia to 85% in Ontario" - " "Parts of British Columbia were affected by flooding due to heavy rains from November 13 to 15, 2021" - " "The carbon tax also led to an 11.0 percentage point increase in environmental efficiency for greenhouse gas emissions over the same period" - " "Five years after job loss, one in four workers displaced from coal mining from 2004 to 2011 saw their annual wages fall by at least $19,000" - " "One in four displaced workers saw their annual wages increase by at least $31,000 during that period"
summary:
```html

Summary

Climate change significantly impacts Canadian society, with extreme heat increasing mortality risk by 2% to 8%. Air conditioning, varying regionally from 32% to 85% household penetration, is crucial for health during heat events. British Columbia's 2021 floods affected regional economies, with up to 15.5% economic impact in the Fraser Valley. British Columbia's carbon tax improved manufacturers' economic and environmental efficiency by 11.9% and 11.0%, respectively, but had mixed effects on air pollutants. Workers displaced from fossil fuel industries experienced varied earnings changes, with some seeing a $19,000 decrease and others a $31,000 increase after five years.

Facts

  • Daily mortality risk during extreme heat events
    • 2% to 8% (increase)
  • Household air conditioning by region (2017)
    • 32% (British Columbia)
    • 85% (Ontario)
  • Regional economic impact of 2021 floods
    • 15.5% (Fraser Valley)
    • 4.6% (Thompson–Nicola)
    • 6.2% (Okanagan–Similkameen)
  • Carbon tax impact on manufacturers (2004-2007 vs. 2008-2012)
    • 11.9% (sales efficiency increase)
    • 11.0% (environmental efficiency increase for greenhouse gases)
    • 7.2% (carbon monoxide efficiency increase)
    • -7.3% (nitrogen oxide efficiency decrease)
  • Displaced workers' earnings after job loss (coal mining, 2004-2011)
    • -$19,000 (1 in 4 workers' annual wages decrease)
    • +$31,000 (1 in 4 workers' annual wages increase)
```
title: Social, economic and health perspectives on climate change

summary:
Summary

Canadian MPs are set to vote on over 200 Conservative amendments to the Sustainable Jobs Act, reduced from an initial 19,600 proposed changes last fall. The Act aims to transition energy workers to clean technology sectors, with Conservatives arguing it will cost jobs in oil and gas. The bill passed a second reading but faced a chaotic committee stage. Liberals accuse Conservatives of using AI for amendments, which the latter denies. Speaker Greg Fergus consolidated amendments to reduce voting time, with up to 64 votes expected, potentially taking over 15 hours to get through them all.

Facts

  • Initial Conservative amendments proposed vs number of amendments to be voted on
    • -99.98% (19,600 to 200)
  • Bill C-50 page count
    • 18 pages
  • Conservative voting against the bill
    • 100% (all Conservatives)
  • Duration of voting on amendments
    • Up to 15 hours
  • Time of first vote to end of session
    • 6 hours (6 p.m. to midnight)
    • carried on to the next day due to a motion passed by the Liberals to protect the health and safety of MP's and their HoC staff
title: Liberals accuse Conservatives of using AI for amendments to jobs bill as votes loom

quotes:
• "Liberals now contend the Conservatives came up with the myriad amendments using artificial intelligence, in order to gum up the government’s agenda."
  • "Energy Minister Jonathan Wilkinson says the bill ensures government accountability and engagement with the people who will be most affected as the world shifts away from fossil fuels toward renewable energy sources."
  • "Conservative critic Shannon Stubbs, however, calls it a blueprint for what she deems the Liberals’ “wide-scale radical economic restructuring.”"
  • "Government House leader Steven MacKinnon said Thursday those amendments were “robo-amendments created by AI.”"
  • "Wilkinson called Stubbs’s accusations “so ridiculous that it almost belies belief.”"
summary:
Summary

Conservative Leader Pierre Poilievre criticized Prime Minister Justin Trudeau for not reading intelligence documents, preferring oral briefings by security officials. During a speech, Poilievre questioned Trudeau's approach amidst reports of China's preference for Trudeau's leadership and interference in Canadian politics. French Prime Minister Gabriel Attal highlighted the global challenge of foreign interference, including cyberattacks and misinformation. Mentioning that "Last month, the French government said it was experiencing attacks with “unprecedented intensity” and established a special crisis centre to restore online services." Trudeau emphasized the importance of leaders critical thinking and active engagement with intelligence for national security.

Facts

  • Justin Trudeau's Intelligence Briefing Practices
    • Relies on oral briefings
    • Receives briefings from national-security adviser or CSIS director
  • China's Alleged Preference for Trudeau
    • Wanted a return of a Liberal minority government in 2021
    • Sought to defeat certain Conservative candidates
  • Foreign Interference Challenge
    • Described as a "huge challenge" by French Prime Minister Gabriel Attal
    • Includes cyberattacks and misinformation
    • France established a special crisis centre
  • Trudeau's Stance on Intelligence
    • Emphasizes critical thinking and questioning of information
    • Has confidence in Canada's security apparatus
title: Pierre Poilievre criticizes Trudeau on intelligence briefing-notes disclosure

summary:
Summary

BCE Inc. executives testified before the parliamentary heritage committee, defending their decision to cut 4,800 jobs and sell 45 radio stations. They argued for a level playing field with global streaming giants, citing nearly $2 billion in regulatory fees paid annually, unlike their international competitors. BCE's restructuring is its largest in 30 years, following a previous cut of 1,300 jobs. Despite falling short of financial targets, BCE awarded executive bonuses and slowed dividend growth to 3%. MPs criticized the impact on local news and BCE's compliance with federal notice requirements for layoffs.

Facts

  • BCE job cuts
    • -4,800 (recent cuts)
    • -1,300 (June, year prior to recent cuts)
  • BCE radio stations sold
    • 45 out of 103
  • Regulatory fees paid by BCE
    • $2-billion annually
  • BCE's profit
    • $2.3-billion (last year)
  • BCE's dividend growth
    • 3% (current)
    • 5% (previous)
  • BCE's investment in news
    • $300-million annually
  • Notice given to government for layoffs
    • Same day as public (Feb. 8)
title: Bell executives defend media job cuts in committee testimony, urge Ottawa to level streaming playing field

National Defence is keeping the facility's exact location confidential for security reasons. The installation will accommodate 198 personnel and feature simulators and drone control systems. National Defence's secrecy extends to withholding information, violating the Access to Information Act in nearly 40% of cases.

```html
  • Number of simulators
    • 2
  • Expected completion year

    • Over $80 billion
```

title: Military drone installation to be built in Ottawa – DND says exact location will remain secret

summary:
Summary

Canadian home sales increased marginally by 0.5% in March, while benchmark home prices fell by 0.3% to C$718,400. Sales are 10% below the 10-year average. The Bank of Canada's potential interest rate cut could stimulate the market as inflation concerns ease. Newly listed properties decreased by 1.6%, but the sales-to-new-listings ratio suggests a balanced market. With strong immigration and tight supply, robust housing demand is expected, yet new construction lags behind. CREA forecasts an 11% rise in home sales for 2024, with prices projected to reach C$760,120 by 2025.

Facts

  • Home Sales (seasonally adjusted)
    • +0.5% (March change)
    • -3.1% (February change)
    • -10% (Below 10-year average)
  • Home Prices
    • -0.3% (March change)
    • C$718,400
  • Interest Rate Cuts
    • Possible in June (Bloomberg economists' survey)
    • Fully priced by July (Traders' expectations)
  • New Listings
    • -1.6% (March change)
  • Sales-to-New-Listings Ratio
    • 57.4% (March ratio)
  • Housing Demand
    • "Robust growth" expected (Policymakers' anticipation)
  • Housing Starts vs. Immigration
    • Not keeping pace (CMHC estimate)
  • Additional Housing Units Needed
    • 3.5 million by 2030 (CMHC estimate)
  • CREA Forecasts
    • +11% this year in home sales increase
    • +7.8% the next year in home sales increase
    • C$760,120 (Projected national average home price in 2025)
title: Home Prices Dip in Canada as Buyers Await Lower Mortgage Rates

quotes:
• "Canada is at greater risk of losing its AAA credit rating than other top-rated countries if the government fails to show fiscal discipline, Royal Bank of Canada has warned on the eve of Finance Minister Chrystia Freeland’s new budget."
  • "“Even though deeper deficits and higher associated sovereign borrowing costs may feel like a distant problem for many Canadians, the impact has the potential to trickle down to most households and businesses,” Battaglia wrote."
summary:
Summary

Canada's AAA credit rating is at risk without fiscal discipline, as warned by RBC ahead of the 2024-2025 budget announcement by Finance Minister Chrystia Freeland. High household debt levels and a softer economy may impact the budget. Provincial examples British Columbia, which faced credit downgrades to AA-, illustrate the potential for increased borrowing costs. These costs could affect households and businesses due to the correlation between government borrowing rates and consumer loan rates.

Key Points

  • Canada's AAA credit rating risk
    • Potential downgrade
    • Increased borrowing costs
  • 2024-2025 fiscal year budget
    • To be released Tuesday, April 16
  • Provincial credit ratings
    • Quebec: Bond yields widened
    • British Columbia: Downgraded to AA-
      • Third downgrade in three years
  • Consumer loan rates
    • Correlated to government borrowing rate
title: Canada’s AAA Credit Rating at Risk From Deeper Deficit, RBC Says

quotes:
• "Canada’s decision to allow first-time buyers to take out mortgages with 30-year amortization periods on new builds will only affect “a sliver” of the country’s highly priced housing market, according to analysts."
  • “The first-time home buyer segment of the market is really small, and then the presale — the new-home segment of the market — is also small.” - Ryan Berlin, senior economist at Vancouver-based real estate firm Rennie
  • "However, new homes are often relatively more expensive and are subject to a 5% goods and services tax, which would offset most of the policy’s benefit, he added."
  • "First-time buyers make up less than half of transactions, with their share falling in favor of investors and move-up buyers, while insured mortgages — the kind covered by the new policy — have fallen to about 15% of new activity, Bank of Montreal senior economist Robert Kavcic wrote in a note."
summary:
Summary

Canada's new policy allows first-time buyers to take out 30-year mortgages on new builds, which analysts believe will minimally impact the housing market. The policy could raise the attainable purchase price for first-time buyers by about 6%, but the effect is dampened by the higher cost of new homes and a 5% goods and services tax. Insured mortgages, which the policy targets, represent only 15% of new activity. The policy may slightly shift activity towards new builds for first-time buyers, but overall market impact is expected to be limited.

Facts

  • Attainable purchase price increase for first-time buyers
    • 6% (rough estimate)
  • Goods and services tax on new homes
    • 5%
  • Share of first-time buyers in transactions
    • Less than half
  • Insured mortgages as a share of new activity
    • 15% of activity
  • Buyer power increase in the targeted market segment
    • 8% (assuming a 5% mortgage rate with a fixed down payment)
title: Canada’s 30-Year Mortgages Seen Helping Small ‘Sliver’ of Market

quotes:
• "Make little mistake, these measures are political and designed to address the federal government’s sagging appeal to younger Canadians—note the way they were delivered—on the assumption they won’t grasp the economics of the likely outcomes"
  • "The last thing that the housing market needs is more demand pressure on top of wildly excessive immigration, little supply, and a strong job market. "
  • "And on broader plans, Freeland reiterated that the deficit will not go higher and that they will respect the fiscal guardrails. Whether that means just the current ending fiscal year, the next one, or the full forecast horizon is unclear."
  • "Ottawa continues to pursue an odd mixture of demand and supply measures that are conflicting with one another if the goal is to improve affordability over time."
  • "It would be unreasonable to throw rate cuts onto the housing market especially after Ottawa just threw jet fuel onto the market."
  • "The hot air and ink that Ottawa spends on the importance of improving affordability through debatable supply side measures is in marked contrast to policies that have induced wildly excessive immigration, very strong government spending, and now easier mortgage terms."
  • "...she did make it clear that higher taxes are coming for relatively higher income households and probably targeted industries. "
summary:
Summary

Canada's Finance Minister Freeland announced measures easing mortgage financing, likely increasing housing demand amidst supply shortages, potentially worsening affordability. Changes include extending amortization periods for first-time homebuyers to 30 years and raising Home Buyers' Plan (HBP) withdrawal limits from $35k to $60k. These measures, while politically appealing, may have unintended consequences, such as increased demand pressuring the Bank of Canada against rate cuts and contributing to the nation's productivity issues. Additionally, tax hikes for higher income households are anticipated, reallocating spending from consumption to government programs.

Key points

  • Gov. announcements:
    • Mortgage Amortization Period
      • 20% (from 25 to 30 years)
      • Effective August 1st
    • Home Buyers' Plan Withdrawal Limit
      • 71.4% increase (from $35k to $60k)
      • Effective on Budget Day
      • combined with the Tax-Free First Home Savings Account allows for:
        • Up to $8k per year contributions to a lifetime limit of $40k
    • HBP Repayment Extension
      • 3 additional years
      • For participants between January 21st, 2022 and December 31st, 2025
    • Lender Contact Requirement
      • Up to 24 months in advance of renewal
    • Amortization Extensions
      • Can be made permanent without fees or penalties
  • New Tax Measures
    • Higher taxes for higher income households
    • Targeted industry taxes
  • Scotiabank points on these announcements:
    • last thing the housing market needs is more demand pressure on top of "wildly excessive immigration, little supply, and a strong job market"
    • housing demand lessens prospects for rate cuts by the BoC
    • more resources being pumped into the "housing beast", the less is available to solve the productivity issue
    • conversion from temporary to permanent amortization lessens the case for BoC policy easing
    • "The peak effects of these changes are designed to pump next Spring’s housing market in an election year more so than this Spring’s market. "
    • "The extended amortization period and raised HBP withdrawals limits will bring more cash into the market to drive house prices higher."
    • amortization length extension is a "gift to builders who will capture some of the incidence effects through the higher new home prices"
    • only applying to first timers discriminates against individuals already in the market who may be facing affordability pressures
    • bear in mind the increased demand in insured mortgages
    • "OSFI’s efforts to tighten mortgage finance markets over the years just suffered a setback"
    • raising taxes on upper income earners could slow consumption growth into an election year and with in GDP growth
title: Scotiabank Daily Points April 12,2024

quotes:
• "Not just by increasing the amount of debt households can carry, but they’re also encouraging first-time buyer’s to divert more money from the country’s capital markets and put it towards housing."

summary:
Summary

Canada introduces policies to aid first-time home buyers and stimulate housing demand. Starting August 1st, 30-year mortgage amortizations are available for new constructions, and RRSP withdrawal limits for down payments double to $60,000. These measures, while presented as affordability solutions, may inflate prices further by increasing credit capacity and diverting funds from capital markets to housing, potentially bailing out developers amid soft new home sales.

Facts

  • Mortgage Amortization Period
    • 20% increase (from 25 to 30 years)
  • RRSP Withdrawal Limit
    • 100% increase (from $30,000 to $60,000)
  • Loan Qualification Increase
    • 7% larger loans
title: Canada Tries To Bail Out Real Estate Developers With 30-Year Mortgages

Summary

Loblaw Cos. Ltd. has introduced No Name Mobile prepaid cellphone plans, offering more data at the same price points as PC Mobile. The plans, which will be available at No Frills stores, run on Bell Canada's 4G network and range from 25GB for $29 to 105GB for $50. Subscribers receive an additional 5GB monthly bonus for automatic account top-ups. All plans feature unlimited Canada and U.S. calling, international texting, and standard call features.

Facts

  • Loblaw Cos. Ltd. stock change
    • -1.06% (-1.06% decrease)
  • PC Mobile carrier existence
    • Since 2005
  • Network used by No Name Mobile
    • Bell Canada's 4G network
  • Data plans comparison (No Name Mobile vs PC Mobile)
    • +5GB (more data at same price points)
  • Price and data for No Name Mobile plans
    • 25GB for $29
    • 55GB for $34
    • 80GB for $40
    • 105GB for $50
  • Automatic top-up bonus
    • +5GB (extra bonus data)
  • Included features in all plans
    • Unlimited calling (Canada and U.S.)
    • International texting
    • Call display, three-way calling, voice mail, call waiting, call-forwarding
title: Loblaw launching No Name Mobile cellphone plans at all No Frills stores

summary:
```html

Summary
```

```html
Canada's health care system, characterized by high spending and poor performance, is constrained by federal policies, particularly the Canada Health Act (CHA) and associated transfers. Canadian health care spending is the highest among developed nations with universal care, yet it underperforms in physician availability, hospital beds, and medical technology. Wait times have nearly tripled since the 1990s. Quebec slightly outperforms other provinces due to different policies. Reforming the CHA and reducing federal transfers could allow provinces to innovate and improve health care outcomes.

Facts

  • Health care spending
    • 1st (highest among universal health care nations)
  • Physician availability
    • Substantially fewer (compared to peer countries)
  • Hospital beds
    • Substantially fewer (compared to peer countries)
  • Medical technology
    • Substantially fewer (compared to peer countries)
  • Wait times
    • Among the longest (in the developed world)
    • Almost tripled (since the early 1990s)
  • Canada Health Transfer (CHT)
    • $49.4 billion (2023-24)
  • Canada Health Act (CHA)
    • 23 sections (10 most relevant to federal impact)
  • Quebec's performance
    • Better (in terms of wait times and overall provincial health system)
```
title: Time to Reform the Canada Health Act

summary:
```html

Summary

Provincial budgets are showing fiscal deterioration due to a weaker economy and rising expenses, increasing government debt. Fiscal anchors set by the federal government and provinces like Ontario, Quebec, Alberta, and Manitoba are being breached, impacting credibility and borrowing costs. Quebec's recent budget indicates higher debt servicing costs, which may affect households and businesses. Canada's fiscal position is vulnerable among AAA rated economies, risking a sovereign rating downgrade. The upcoming federal budget must maintain fiscal discipline to avoid negative impacts on borrowing rates for all Canadians.

Facts

  • Ontario's fiscal anchor breach
    • 200% (net debt-to-revenue ratio exceeded)
  • Quebec's net debt-to-GDP target
    • 30% (target by 2037-38)
  • Spread between Ontario and Quebec 10-year bond yields
    • Highest differential in over a year
  • Canada's sovereign rating
    • AAA (current rating)
    • More vulnerable (compared to other AAA economies)
  • Net debt burden growth expectation
    • Until at least fiscal 2025-26 (for all provinces except Alberta and New Brunswick)
```
title: Proof Point: Governments face higher interest costs when straying from fiscal anchors

```html
BuildForce Canada's report highlights an 83% increase in the residential construction workforce required to meet Canada's target of 5.8 million new homes over the next decade. Housing starts need to nearly double, peaking at 691,600 in 2029, with a 109% increase in construction investment. Over 22% of the current workforce will retire within ten years, with 40% over 55.     • 691,600 in 2029
  • Residential construction investment increase
    • 109%
  • Workforce retiring over the next decade
    • 22%
  • Workforce over the age of 55
    • 40%
```

summary:
Summary

In March 2024, the Canadian housing market showed stability with a slight 0.5% increase in home sales and a 0.3% dip in the National Composite MLS® Home Price Index (HPI) month-over-month. Year-over-year, the HPI rose by 0.7%, and the actual national average sale price increased by 2%. New listings decreased by 1.6% from the previous month. The sales-to-new listings ratio was 57.4%, indicating a balanced market. Inventory remained at 3.8 months, consistent with February 2024, and below the long-term average of five months.

Key Points

  • “home sales and prices were mostly unchanged on a month-over-month basis in March 2024”
  • Home sales activity:
    • +0.5% between February and March 2024
    • “holding around 10% below an average of the last 10 years”
  • Home prices activity:
    • National Composite MLS Home Price Index (HPI) down 0.3%
    • +0.7% YoY
  • Actual (not seasonally adjusted) Data:$
    • monthly activity +0.5% MoM
    • New listings +1.6% MoM
    • National average sale +2.0% YoY in March 2024
    • Number of transactions +1.7% from March 2023:
    • National average home price in Jan 2023:
      • $698,530
      • +2% YoY
  • Sales -to-new listings:
    • March 2024: 57.4%
      • Long term average is 55%
    • “between 45% and 65% is generally consistent with balanced housing market conditions” :
      • Anything below or above indicates sellers and buyers markets
  • Inventory:
    • 3.8 months on a national basis
    • Unchanged
    • Long term avg is 5 months
  • TD analysis:
    • Expect firmer sales and home prices to coincide with the BoC rate cuts although affordability pressure “will likely keep the gains from being even stronger.”
title: Hints of Active Spring Market in March Housing Data

quotes:
• "The Consumer Price Index rose 6.8% on an annual average basis in 2022, the largest increase in 40 years, taking an outsized bite out of real annual wages, salaries and commissions reported by tax filers in that year."
  • "Tax filers reported median wages of $45,380, down 1.6% from 2021 after adjusting for inflation"
  • "The largest declines in educational services (-5.3%) and public administration (-5.2%)"
  • "Inflation-adjusted wages also rose for low-wage workers from 2021 to 2022, highlighted by a 10.9% increase in earnings at the first wage decile"
  •  "Inflation-adjusted annual median wages, salaries and commissions were higher in 2022 compared with 2019"
summary:
Summary

In 2022, the Consumer Price Index (CPI) saw its largest increase in 40 years at 6.8%, which significantly impacted real annual wages. Median wages dropped by 1.6% after inflation adjustments. Employment in lower wage sectors like arts, entertainment, and food services increased, with median wages in these sectors rising but still remaining the lowest. Higher wage sectors experienced decreases in inflation-adjusted median wages, with the largest drops in educational services and public administration. Low-wage workers saw a 10.9% increase at the first decile, while higher earners, especially at the eighth decile, experienced declines.

Facts

  • CPI rose 6.8% on an annual avg. basis in 2022
    • Largest increase in 40 years
  • Median reported wages of tax filers of $45,380, - 1.6% from 2021
    • Sectors massively affected by the lockdowns bounced back
      • Arts, Entertainment, Recreation: +1.6% (1.6% vs. 1.4%)
      • Accommodation and Food Services: +7.1% (7.1% vs. 6.3%)
  • Median annual wages were higher in 2022 than in 2019:
    • Due to strong wage growth and low inflation observed in 2021
  • Median wages by province and territory
    • All saw decreases other than Nunavut, Quebec and new Brunswick
    • Breakdown by province
  • “sector that were less affected by the pandemic saw decreases in their inflation-adjusted median annual wages in 2022”
    • Breakdown by sector
  • Inflation-adjusted lower wage earners saw increases meanwhile higher wage earners saw decrease in their earnings
    • Details
  • Earnings Increase by Wage Decile (2021 to 2022)
    • First Decile: +10.9%
    • Second Decile: +5.5%
    • Eighth Decile: -2.5%
  • Median Annual Wages Comparison (2022 vs. 2019)
    • British Columbia: +11.8%
    • Quebec: +7.0%
    • Yukon: +6.7%
    • Prairie Provinces and Newfoundland and Labrador: -0.5%
title: Annual wages, salaries and commissions of T1 tax filers, 2022

  • "Freight revenues, which accounted for 89.5% of the rail industry"s total operating revenues in 2022, increased 12.5% from 2021 to $17.7 billion"
  • "Passenger revenues more than doubled from $138 million in 2021 to $345 million in 2022"
  • "Total rail operating expenses rose 16.4% to $12.7 billion in 2022"
  • "With more freight to haul and higher global oil prices, fuel expenditures by railways increased 50.8%, from $1.9 billion in 2021 to $2.9 billion in 2022"
  • "In 2022, the average number of railway employees reached 32,387, up 1.3% from 2021"
  • "Labour productivity—revenue tonne-kilometres per railway employee—increased 7.1% to 14.2 million"
  • "The sharp increase in exports of energy products helped offset the overall decline in freight tonnage"
  • "The overall rail tonnage in 2022 was the lowest it had been since 2017"
summary:
Summary

Canadian railways saw a 14.4% increase in operating revenues in 2022, reaching $19.7 billion. Freight revenues grew by 12.5% to $17.7 billion, accounting for 89.5% of total revenues. Passenger revenues more than doubled to $345 million. Operating expenses rose by 16.4% to $12.7 billion, with fuel expenditures up by 50.8%. The average number of railway employees increased by 1.3%, with total wages up by 5.8%. Revenue tonne-kilometres increased by 8.4%. Freight tonnage slightly declined by 1.7%, with notable commodity composition changes.

Facts

  • Operating Revenues
    • +14.4% (Total of $19.7 billion)
  • Freight Revenues
    • +12.5% (Total of $17.7 billion)
    • represents 89.5% of rail industry's total operating revenues
  • Passenger Revenues
    • +150% (+$207 million)
    • Total of $345 million
  • Operating Expenses
    • +16.4% ( Total of $12.7 billion)
    • Fuel Expenditures
      • +50.8% / + $1.0 billion (Total of $2.9 billion)
    • Wages and Salaries
      • +7.1% (Total of $2.0 billion)
    • Way and structures
      • +6.0% (Total of $2.8 billion)
    • operating ratio (expenses as a ration of revenue)
      • 0.64 (+0.01 from a year prior)
  • Labour
    • Employees: +1.3% (Total of 32,387)
    • Wages: +5.8% (Total of $3.4 billion)
    • Productivity: +7.1%
  • Freight Tonnage
    • "lowest it has been since 2017"
    • -1.7% (Total of 315.7 million tonnes)
  • Western Canada Loadings
    • 3/4 of all commodities originating from Canada came from Western Canada
    • Energy Products: Mixed
      • fuel oils and crude petroleum down 11.2%
      • coal shipments increase 2.6%
    • Wheat: -11.2% (Total of 19.9 million tonnes)
    • Canola: -26.3% (Total of 6.8 million tonnes)
    • Potash: Slight decrease (Total of 23.0 million tonnes)
  • Eastern Canada Loadings:
    • 26.9% of all commodities originated from Canada came from Eastern Canada
    • "has changed very little in the last couple of years"
    • iron ore/concentrates and mixed loads/unidentified frieght were the two dominant commodities
title: Rail transportation, 2022

quotes:
• "Among renters, 3% experienced an eviction in the previous 12 months, which represents 1% of all Canadians. "
  • "From 2011 to 2021, the growth in renter households (+22%) was more than double that of owner households (+8%)."
  • "The Canada Mortgage and Housing Corporation (CMHC) estimated that the average rent growth increased by 8% year over year in 2023."
  • "Over half of evictions are due to landlord factors, which include own use, sale of property, and major repairs or renovations"

  • "Nearly 7 in 10 evictees report having low trust in others"
summary:
Summary

Recent Canadian data shows 3% of renters faced eviction in the past year, representing 1% of all Canadians. Renter households grew by 22% from 2011 to 2021, doubling the growth of owner households. Average rent increased by 8% in 2023. Over half of evictions were due to landlord factors, with 30% for own use, 17% for sale, and 4% for major repairs. Financial difficulties were cited by 59% of evictees, with 18% evicted for not paying rent. Mental health issues and disabilities are more prevalent among evictees, and 69% of them report low trust in others.

Facts

  • Renter eviction rate
    • 3% (percentage of renters evicted)
    • 1% (percentage of all Canadians evicted)
  • Average rent growth (CMHC Year over year, 2023)
    • 8% (increase in average rent)
    • regional variability:
      • high of 983% increase in Hamilton, Ontario from 2017 to 2022
  • Difficulty paying rent
    • 59% (percentage of evictees with financial difficulties)
    • 32% (percentage of total population with financial difficulties)
    • 18% (percentage of evictions due to difficulty paying rent)
  • Mental health among evictees
    • 46% (percentage reporting fair or poor mental health)
  • Disability among evictees
    • 28% (percentage identified with having a disability)
title: Recently evicted people tend to be younger, have financial difficulties, and report having low trust in others

The Elon Musk-led company attributed the fall to logistical issues, but analysts say that slowing demand for EVs also played a role." - "General Motors Co.’s chief executive Mary Barra referred to this slowdown as well on an earnings call in January, when she said the slowing pace of EV growth had created some uncertainty." - "In 2023, ZEVs accounted for about 10.8 per cent of all such registrations, according to Statistics Canada, nearly a 50 per cent increase from 2022 and a 114.6 per cent increase compared to 2021." - "However, the pace of sales has been cut in half, according to J.D. Today, it takes about 55 days to sell an electric vehicle, compared to 51 days for a gasoline car." - "But the market now seems to be looking for more general buyers at a mass level, which has proven to be difficult for several reasons, including high prices and poor performance." - "EV owners reported 79 per cent more problems with their powertrains over the past three years than owners of gas-powered vehicles, according to Consumer Reports’ latest annual car reliability survey." - "Another major issue is the lack of charging stations." - "A survey of EV drivers conducted by NGO Pollution Probe in 2023 said 56 per cent of EV owners felt that the power supply at public charging stations was not consistent." - "On average, an EV costs about $15,000 more than a gas-powered car before any government incentives are applied. " - "Add to this the high-interest rate environment and the current housing market, and it’s a “tall order to ask the average Canadian” to buy an EV," - "The recent cutbacks from automakers send an obvious message that isn’t well understood by the government, Kingston said."

```html

Summary

Canada's target for 20% of new vehicle sales to be electric by 2026 is at risk as automakers delay EV plans and sales slow. Ford postponed EV production in Oakville to 2027, citing technology advancements and market growth. Tesla's deliveries dropped, partly due to logistical issues. ZEVs made up 10.8% of Canada's new vehicle registrations in 2023, a significant increase from previous years, but the sales pace has slowed, with EVs taking longer to sell than gas vehicles. High prices, performance issues, and insufficient charging infrastructure contribute to the slowdown. Government incentives may not be sufficient to boost EV adoption.

Facts

  • Canada's 2026 EV target
    • 20% of new vehicle sales
  • Ford's EV production delay
    • 2 years (2027 from 2025)
  • Tesla's quarterly deliveries decline
    • First time in nearly 4 years
  • ZEV registrations in Canada
    • 10.8% in 2023
    • 50% increase from 2022
    • 114.6% increase from 2021
  • Average days to sell an EV
    • 22 days in early 2023
    • 55 days currently
  • Average days to sell a gas-powered vehicle
    • 42 days in early 2023
    • 51 days currently
  • EV powertrain problems reported
    • 79% more than gas vehicles over 3 years
  • Public charger target by 2035
    • 442,000 chargers
  • Public charger daily installation requirement
    • 100 chargers per day
  • EV owners reporting inconsistent power supply at charging stations
    • 56% in 2023
  • Price difference between EV and gas-powered car
    • $15,000 more before incentives
    • $20,000 more for specific EV models
  • Federal government's iZEV program
    • Up to $5,000 incentive
    • Potential funds depletion by 2025
  • Quebec's incentive program end year
    • 2027
  • Recommended increase in ZEV incentives
    • To $10,000 per vehicle
  • Charger infrastructure cost by 2035
    • More than $50 billion
```
title: 'Tall order to ask the average Canadian': EVs are twice as hard to sell today

```html
Summary

Canada’s federal government has implemented artificial intelligence in nearly 300 projects. Joanna Redden's research shows 95% of these AI tools are used by federal agencies. The AI is applied in diverse areas, including tax case outcomes, visa application sorting, and hiring diversity. Concerns are raised about the lack of public debate and transparency, especially with the proposed Artificial Intelligence and Data Act not fully covering government AI use. Some AI applications have become permanent, while others, like the Public Health Agency's social media analysis for suicide signs, were discontinued.

Facts
```

summary:
Summary

Canadian accounting firms may have spent nearly $1-billion on compliance with new bare trust reporting rules before they were deferred for the 2023 tax year. A survey by Video Tax News' Joseph Devaney, involving 118 firms, suggests significant financial impact due to the premature enforcement of these rules. Firms spent an average of $13,000 on staff training and charged $11,000 for preparing files, with additional costs of $12,000 for unsubmitted or unbilled work. The CRA's late reversal of the rules, just before the filing deadline, led to wasted resources and strained client relationships.

Facts

  • Estimated total compliance cost
    • $905-million
  • Average cost per firm for staff training
    • $13,000
  • Average fees charged to clients for prepared files
    • $11,000
  • Average costs related to unsubmitted or unbilled work
    • $12,000
  • Percentage of firms not planning to handle bare trust returns
    • 12%
title: Costs for CRA’s bare trusts rules neared $1-billion, survey of accounting firms suggests

```html
Summary

Alberta's government has not provided details on achieving its 2050 net-zero target, nor established consultation groups, examined the oil sands emissions cap, or reported progress on its Emissions Reduction and Energy Development Plan. The plan relies on undeveloped technology and regulations, and lacks interim targets. Critics argue this inaction risks Alberta's economy by not preparing for a net-zero future. Despite this, the government cites support for nuclear reactors, hydrogen, and carbon capture as achievements. Alberta remains the highest emitter in Canada, with no short-term targets or accountability in place.

Facts

  • 2050 net-zero target
    • No details released
  • Environmental footprint assessment
    • Not completed
  • Consultation groups
    • Not established
  • Oil sands emissions cap
    • Examination not conducted
  • Progress reports
    • Not released
  • Technology and regulations
    • Dependent on undeveloped aspects
  • Interim targets
    • Not set
  • Emissions since 2005
    • Highest increase in Canada
  • Short-term targets
    • Not established
  • Accountability mechanisms
    • Not in place
  • Government achievements
    • Support for nuclear reactors, hydrogen, carbon capture
  • Methane emissions reduction
    • Proposed 75 to 80% reduction from 2014 levels
```
title: Alberta fails to move needle on emissions reduction plan

Summary

In 2020, Canada harvested 293 million tonnes of ecosystem services, with 51% from agriculture and 49% from forests. Prairie provinces produced 70% of total field crops (including corn for silage and tame hay) in 2022. Forests yielded 142 million tonnes of timber, with British Columbia leading at 38%. Maple syrup production fell by 40% in 2023 compared to the year prior due to weather conditions. Marine and freshwater harvests declined to 0.78 million tonnes in 2021 from 1.1 million tonnes in 2002. Farmed shellfish production increased by 41% in 2021 compared to the year prior, with Prince Edward Island contributing 53%.

quotes:
• "Combined with the baseline outlook for completions, closing the housing gap in Canada would result in 3.1 million net housing units completed by 2030, which translates into 436,000 units completed annually, on average, over 2024 to 2030."
  • "We estimate that suppressed household formation in Canada amounted to 631,000 households in 2021. That is, the number of households in 2021 in Canada would have been 631,000 (4.1 per cent) higher if attainable housing options had existed."
  • "Combined with our baseline outlook, closing the housing gap would result in 3.1 million net housing units completed by 2030, which translates into 436,000 units completed annually, on average, over 2024 to 2030. This pace of housing completion would represent an increase of 80 per cent above the record level of net completions in 2023, sustained for 7 years."
summary:
Summary

The report analyzes Canada's housing market, revealing a significant surge in household formation to 460,000 new households in 2023, far surpassing the 242,000 net housing completions. Suppressed household formation, due to a lack of attainable housing, reached 631,000 households in 2021. The total vacancy rate hit a record low of 5.1% in 2023, indicating a growing housing demand. Projections suggest that from 2024 to 2030, household formation will continue to outpace housing completions, potentially lowering the vacancy rate to 3.9% by 2025. To close the housing gap by 2030, an additional 1.3 million units are needed, increasing the annual average completions by 181,000 units.

Key Points

  • Household formation (change in the number of households):
    • 2019:
      • 238,000 household formation
      • 188,000 housing units completed
    • 2023:
      • 460,000 household formation
      • 242,000 housing units completed
    • suppressed household formation (number of households not formed due to lack of attainable housing) 2021: 
      • 631,000 households (4.1%)
  • Total vacancy rate in 2023 using the Bank of Canada approach
    • 5.1% total vacancy rate
    • -1.8 percentage points below the 2000-2019 avg. of 6.9%
    • 2025 and 2030 prediction:
      • annual avg. of household formation, 272,000 and household completions, 255,000
      • 2025: 3.9%
      • 2030: 4.0%
      • methodology
  • Housing gap:
    • def: number of additional units required to return total vacancy rate to its long-term avg. by 2030 (accounting for household suppressions)
    • additional 1.3 million units to close the housing gap by 2030
      • 181,000 units annually over 2024-2030 
    • Total figures:
      • 3.1 million net housing units completed by 2030
      • translates into 436,000 unit completed annually on avg. over 2024-2030
      • increase of 80% above the record level of net completion in 2023, sustained for 7 years
    • housing gap in alternative scenarios:
      • higher construction and lower population growth: 0.7 million units
      • lower construction and higher population growth: 1.9 million units 
    • CMHC estimated housing supply: 3.5 million:
      • includes restoring housing affordability to levels "last seen around 2004"
title: Household Formation and the Housing Stock

quotes: "The prime minister’s six-day trip, accompanied by his son, to “strengthen ties” in the Indo-Pacific region in September cost taxpayers nearly $2 million, with nearly $200,000 spent on in-flight catering." - "Costs for the trip included $190,000 on in-flight catering, $643,000 for aircraft handling and fuel fees, $422,000 for lodging, $129,000 for ground transportation and $427,000 for RCMP security costs." - "“I guess one way to beat the high cost of groceries in Canada is to take a government work trip and bill taxpayers for fancy airplane food,” said Canadian Taxpayers Federation Federal Director Franco Terrazzano."
summary:
Summary

Prime Minister Justin Trudeau's six-day Indo-Pacific trip cost taxpayers $1.9 million, with significant expenses on in-flight catering, aircraft fees, lodging, transportation, and security. The trip aimed to strengthen international partnerships and address global challenges. The entourage faced a mechanical issue with their aircraft in India, leading to additional costs. The Canadian Taxpayers Federation criticized the spending amid Canada's debt. Costs were covered by Global Affairs Canada, the Department of National Defence, and the RCMP, with the impact of international summits on costs acknowledged.

Facts

- Total cost: 1.9% ($1,908,243) - In-flight catering: 9.95% ($190,000) - Aircraft handling and fuel fees: 33.7% ($643,000) - Lodging: 22.1% ($422,000) - Ground transportation: 6.76% ($129,000) - RCMP security costs: 22.38% ($427,000) - Official gifts: 0.13% ($2,500) - COP28 climate conference cost: 73.6% ($1.4 million) - Number of rooms in Singapore and Jakarta: 53 - Number of rooms in New Delhi: 58
title: PM's six-day Indo-Pacific trip cost $2M, including $200K in catering

summary:
Summary

Ottawa's proposed tax credits for low-carbon investments may disadvantage Indigenous corporations, which could qualify for a smaller credit (15%) than other companies (30%), with a slower implementation. Indigenous leaders and clean-energy developers are concerned this disparity could hinder Indigenous participation in renewable energy projects. Despite the urgency to compete with U.S. subsidies, the Canadian government is reluctant to amend the legislation, citing cost containment and the need for prompt passage. The tax credits are part of Canada's strategy to attract green capital but face criticism for potential inflexibility and exclusion of certain clean technologies.

Facts

  • Indigenous corporation tax credit
    • 15% 
  • Non-Indigenous company tax credit
    • 30%
title: Ottawa rebuffs calls for last-minute fixes to green subsidies as Indigenous leaders sound alarm

  • "The government’s decision to count long-term care beds as housing units is tantamount to “cooking the books,” said Frank Clayton, co-founder and senior research fellow at the Centre for Urban Research and Land Development at Toronto Metropolitan University."
  • "For instance, Peterborough is receiving $1.88-million from the province for exceeding its 345-unit housing target with 506 new housing units. Provincial data show that half the city’s total number of new units – 256 – are long-term care beds. "
  • "Some cities have complained about the government’s metrics and argue the province should instead judge them by the number of building permits they issue."
summary:
Summary

Ontario included long-term care beds in housing targets, enabling Peterborough, Brantford, Sudbury, and North Bay to meet their 2023 goals and receive extra funding. Without these inclusions, the cities would have fallen short. Long-term care beds made up 9% of Ontario's new homes in 2022, helping the province nearly meet its 110,000 target. Critics argue this approach misrepresents housing achievements, as long-term care beds are not private dwellings. The province awarded $6.8 million to these cities, with plans to consider other institutional housing types for future calculations.

Facts

  • Ontario's 2022 housing target
    • 99% (109,011 new homes)
  • Long-term care beds as a percentage of new homes
    • 9% (long-term care beds included)
  • Total bonus funding awarded
    • $6.8 million (to four cities: Peterborough, Brantford, Sudbury and North Bay)
  • Peterborough
    • 506 new housing units (exceeded 345-unit target)
    • 50% (256 long-term care beds)
    • $1.88 million (bonus funding)
  • Brantford
    • 788 new housing units (exceeded 733-unit target)
    • 25.4% (200 long-term care beds)
    • $3.07 million (highest bonus funding)
  • Sudbury
    • 436 new homes (exceeded 279-unit target)
    • 36.7% (160 long-term care beds)
    • $1.52 million (bonus funding)
  • North Bay
    • 202 new units (exceeded target)
    • 79.2% (160 long-term care beds)
    • $400,000 (bonus funding)
  • Cities meeting 2023 allocations
    • 52% (26 out of 50 cities)
title: Ontario awarded four cities millions for meeting housing goals after count tallied care beds

quotes:
• "Women (61%) made up the majority of admissions, followed by children accompanying an adult (38%)"
  • "The number of admissions in 2022/2023 was 44% higher compared with admissions in 2020/2021, during the pandemic"
  • "Just over half (53%) of these residents were women and 45% were accompanying children"
  • "A current or former intimate partner was the abuser for just over three-quarters (76%) of women residing in shelters on the snapshot date"
  • "30% of women residing in shelters for reasons of abuse on the snapshot date were of Indigenous identity"
  • "Just over three-quarters (77%) of the 7,375 funded beds in short-term facilities across Canada were occupied on the snapshot date"
  • "Approximately 31% of facilities reported turning away women on the snapshot date"
  • "Facilities that turned away women indicated that the majority of women (83%) were turned away because the shelter was full"
summary:
Summary

In 2022/2023, Canadian residential facilities for victims of abuse admitted 67,430 individuals, matching pre-pandemic levels. Women constituted 61% of admissions, with children at 38%. Admissions surged 44% from 2020/2021. On April 13, 2023, 7,686 were sheltered, 53% women and 45% children. Emotional/psychological abuse affected 65% of women, with 76% abused by an intimate partner. Indigenous women and children were overrepresented, at 30% and 24%, respectively. Short-term shelters were 77% full, with 33% at capacity and 31% turning away women, predominantly due to fullness (83%).

Facts

  • Total admissions in 2022/2023
    • 44% (increase from 2020/2021)
    • 67,430 (total number)
  • Women as a percentage of admissions
    • 61%
  • Children accompanying adults as a percentage of admissions
    • 38%
  • Residents on snapshot date

    • 53%
  • Children as a percentage of residents on snapshot date
    • 45%

    • 65%
  • Women experiencing physical abuse
    • 58%
  • Women experiencing financial abuse
    • 39%
  • Abuse by a current or former intimate partner
    • 76%
  • Indigenous women as a percentage of shelter residents
    • 30%
  • Indigenous children as a percentage of accompanying children in facilities
    • 24%
  • Funded beds in short-term facilities occupied on snapshot date
    • 77%
  • Short-term facilities at or over capacity
    • 33%
  • Facilities turning away women on snapshot date
    • 31%
  • Reason for turning away women (shelter full)
    • 83%
title: Canadian residential facilities for victims of abuse, 2022/2023

summary:
Summary

In March 2024, international arrivals to Canada increased by 16.5%. Non-resident air arrivals rose by 15.5% to 575,500, with US residents' air trips peaking before Easter. Canadian residents returning by air grew by 8.3% to 2.2 million, with a notable increase during Saint Patrick's Day weekend. US-resident automobile trips to Canada surged by 24.3% to 862,100, while Canadian-resident return automobile trips increased by 23.3% to 2.1 million. These figures approach pre-pandemic levels, indicating a significant recovery in cross-border travel.

Facts

    • 16.5% (Increase from March 2023)
  • Non-resident air arrivals
    • 15.5% (575,500 total arrivals)
    • US residents
      • 36.6% (Average of 12,100 arrivals per day before Easter)
    • Excluding Toronto Pearson International Airport Terminal 1

  • Canadian-resident return air trips
    • 8.3% (2.2 million total return trips)
    • Saint Patrick's Day weekend
      • 9.5% (161,400 arrivals)
    • Excluding Toronto Pearson International Airport Terminal 1
      • 18.1% (Higher than 1.4 million trips in March 2019)
  • US-resident automobile trips
    • 24.3% (862,100 total trips)
    • Before Easter
      • 84.1% (Average of 47,400 arrivals per day)
    • Compared to March 2019
      • 98.4% (Of the number of trips)
  • Canadian-resident return automobile trips
    • 23.3% (2.1 million total return trips)
    • Saint Patrick's Day weekend
      • 30.3% (233,600 arrivals)
    • Compared to March 2019
      • 92.1% (Of the number of trips)
title: Leading indicator of international arrivals to Canada, March 2024

quotes: “It’s so easy to say ‘this is illegal and we’ll buy it back,’ but they took a category of firearms which is so modular in nature,” Winkel said. summary:
```html

Summary

The Canadian government's ban on "assault-style" firearms and the associated mandatory buyback program is proving to be more complex and costly than anticipated. The Canadian Sporting Arms and Ammunition Association (CSAAA) highlights the difficulty due to the modular nature of these firearms, which consist of numerous parts and accessories. The amnesty period for banned guns is set to end in October 2025, by which time compensation for expropriated items is expected to be provided to owners and retailers.

Facts

  • Amnesty period expiration
    • October 2025
  • Complexity of the buyback
    • High due to modularity of firearms
  • Number of components
    • Hundreds of different parts and accessories
  • Government's anticipation
    • Lower than actual complexity and cost
  • Compensation requirement
    • For owners and retailers of banned items
```
title: 'The costs have ballooned': Liberal government failed to anticipate difficulty of gun 'buyback,' association says

summary:

```html
Summary

From 2009 to 2023, Canada saw a consistent rise in top personal income tax rates, with the federal rate increasing to 33% for incomes over $200,000 in 2016. Newfoundland and Labrador experienced the largest hike of 10.3 percentage points (23.1%). High marginal tax rates discourage economic activity, placing Canada at a competitive disadvantage, especially compared to the US. Newfoundland and Labrador have the highest combined rate at 54.80%, with Canada's rates being uncompetitive at various income levels. By 2022, Canada had the 5th highest top tax rate among 38 industrialized countries.

Facts

  • Federal top tax rate increase
    • 4% (from 29% to 33%)
  • Provincial top tax rate increases
    • Newfoundland and Labrador: 10.3 percentage points (23.1%)
    • Ontario: 7.1 percentage points (15.3%)
    • Quebec: 5.1 percentage points (10.6%)
  • Combined top personal income tax rates in Canada
    • Newfoundland and Labrador: 54.80%
    • Nova Scotia: 54.00%
    • Ontario: 53.53%
  • Canada's international tax competitiveness (2022)
    • 5th highest combined top tax rate out of 38 industrialized countries
  • Canada's tax rate ranking before federal change (2014)
    • 13th highest combined tax rate
```

title: Canada’s Rising Personal Tax Rates and Falling Tax Competitiveness, 2024

```html
Summary

The Fish, Food and Allied Workers Union in Newfoundland and Labrador is protesting the low crab prices set for this season at $2.60 per pound, a significant drop from last year's average of $6.87 per pound. The price, determined by a government-appointed panel using a formula from the Association of Seafood Producers, is deemed unfair by the union, which argues for a fairer share. Last year's protests led to a six-week fishing halt and a review of the price-setting process, but the union feels this year's panel ignored the proposed fairer formula.

Facts

  • 2022 season starting crab price
    • $2.20 per pound
  • 2021 seafood export value
    • $883 million (Snow crab)
  • Total 2021 fisheries value
    • $1.6 billion
```
title: Harvesters refusing to fish crab in Newfoundland and Labrador, saying price too low

```html
Summary

A Canadian intelligence report revealed that China interfered in Canada's 2019 and 2021 elections, favoring candidates perceived as pro-PRC or neutral. The report, disclosed at a public inquiry, indicated that China conducted disinformation campaigns and transferred funds for interference. Prime Minister Trudeau downplayed the interference, while the Conservative Party claimed it affected their results. Intelligence briefings on foreign interference were provided to top officials, including Trudeau. The Critical Election Incident Public Protocol panel chose not to publicly warn about the interference to avoid confusion and maintain impartiality.
```

quotes: • "Immigrants admitted to Canada as children are generally more likely to participate in postsecondary education during early adulthood and have higher median wages from the ages of 25 to 30 years"
summary:
Summary

In Canada, immigrants admitted as children (14 years of aged or younger) since 1980 make up one-fifth of total immigrants. They are more likely to pursue postsecondary education (based on claimed tuition tax credits) and earn higher median wages by age 25 compared to their peers. The Longitudinal Immigration Database (IMDB) Children Data Module reveals that 77.3% of immigrants admitted by age 4 attend postsecondary education, compared to 59.9% of all Canadian 20-year-olds. By 30, these immigrants earn a median wage of $54,900, surpassing the $46,690 median for all Canadians of the same age.

Facts

  • Postsecondary education participation (age 20)
    • 77.3% (admitted at age 4 or younger)
    • 69.9% (admitted at ages 5 to 9)
    • 61.3% (admitted at ages 10 to 14)
    • 59.9% (all Canadian taxfilers)
  • Median wage at age 30
    • $54,900 for immigrants admitted as children
    • $46,690 for all Canadian taxfilers
title: Socioeconomic outcomes of immigrants admitted to Canada as children, 2022

summary:
Summary

Canadian agricultural commodity prices saw varied trends in February. Wheat prices dropped for the seventh month due to global supply and competition, with Saskatchewan experiencing the largest decline at -3.1%. Soybean prices also fell, led by Manitoba at -9.0% and on a year-over-year basis, Manitoba once again saw the largest decline of -25.3%. Canola prices decreased across Canada, with Quebec seeing a -10.1% drop. Conversely, dry pea prices rose, with Saskatchewan up by +6.3%. Slaughter cattle prices increased, with Quebec up by +13.7%, and feeder cattle prices rose, with New Brunswick up by +28.9%. Slaughter hog prices rebounded, with Alberta seeing a +12.5% increase.

Facts

  • Wheat Prices
    • -3.1% (Saskatchewan)
    • -2.5% (Alberta)
    • -2.5% (Manitoba)
  • Soybean Prices
    • -25.3% (Manitoba, year-over-year)
    • -21.2% (Ontario, year-over-year)
    • -19.3% (Quebec, year-over-year)
    • -9.0% (Manitoba)
    • -5.0% (Ontario)
    • -4.4% (Quebec)
  • Canola Prices
    • -10.1% (Quebec)
    • -8.1% (Saskatchewan)
    • -7.4% (Manitoba)
    • -1.7% (Ontario)
  • Dry Pea Prices
    • +6.3% (Saskatchewan)
    • +5.5% (Alberta)
    • +4.1% (Manitoba)

    • +13.7% (Quebec)
    • +1.0% to +13.7% (across all provinces)

    • +5.1% (Manitoba)

file_2: Justice and Attorney General of Canada
quotes: "Police seizures of hydromorphone have climbed in British Columbia since the province moved to prescribe the opioid as an alternative to toxic, illicit drugs, according to Health Canada data." - "Inspector Conor King with the Victoria Police Department said that while the Health Canada data paint a concerning picture about the increase in police seizures of hydromorphone in B.C., the drug accounts for only a tiny fraction of substances seized. "
summary:
```html

Summary

Since British Columbia began prescribing hydromorphone as a safer opioid supply, seizures of the drug by police have increased, reaching 408 in 2023. Health Canada's data indicates hydromorphone accounts for about 3% of drug seizures in B.C., while fentanyl comprises nearly 30%. The majority of prescribed hydromorphone (86%) is for pain, with 14% for safer supply. Concerns about diversion to the illicit market have prompted calls for better monitoring. Critics argue for ending such programs, while proponents seek improved safeguards like witnessed dosing.

Facts

  • Hydromorphone seizures in B.C.
    • 2012-2020: < 100 annually
    • 2023: 408
  • Percentage of drug seizures analyzed by Health Canada
    • Hydromorphone: 3%
    • Fentanyl: nearly 30%
  • Prescription purposes in B.C.
    • Pain: 86%
    • Safer supply: 14%
  • Opioid alternatives dispensed (December)
    • Total: 4,212 people
    • Hydromorphone recipients: 3,656
  • Seizure comparison with other provinces
    • New Brunswick: 5%
    • Nova Scotia: 8%
```
title: B.C. police seizures of medical opioids on the rise, causing concerns safer-supply pills are being diverted
