quotes:
• "Canada will spend an additional $8.1-billion on defence in the next five years but will not meet its NATO spending targets and has no existing plans to do so, officials said while unveiling the country’s renewed defence policy."
  • "Officials at a technical briefing said there is no fixed date to hit NATO’s spending targets."
summary:
Summary

Canada's new defence policy will increase spending by $8.1-billion over five years, raising defence spending from 1.38% to 1.76% of GDP by 2029-30. Despite this, Canada will not meet the NATO target of 2% of GDP. The spending increase includes significant investments in intelligence, cyber operations, and long-range missile capabilities, and promises to buy new tactical helicopter but it doesn't fund the purchase of new helicopters. The military does face a personnel shortage of nearly 15,000. Two of the most significant spends on new capabilities over the next five years are $917-million to enhance Canada’s intelligence and cyber operations and $401-million for long-range missile capabilities. Under the plan, the gov. is promising to spend more on the basics over the next five year which include $1.9-billion to sustain naval vessels, $1.8-billion on ammunition supply and production, and $1.4-billion on sustaining military equipment.

Key Points

  • Defence spending increase
    • 27.54% (from 1.38% to 1.76% of GDP)
    • $8.1-billion (over five years)
      • Intelligence and cyber operations investment: $917-million
      • Long-range missile capabilities investment: $401-million
      • Naval vessels sustainment: $1.9-billion
      • Ammunition supply and production: $1.8-billion
      • Military equipment sustainment: $1.4-billion
title: Defence policy update falls short of NATO 2% spending target

quotes:
• "If anything, Canada is moving in the wrong direction. There were around 240,000 housing unit starts in 2023, down from roughly 271,000 in 2021, according to figures from Canada Mortgage and Housing Corp. This doesn’t bode well for completions over the rest of the decade."
  • "The situation has become a major political headache for various parties, but especially the federal Liberals, who have been languishing in polls for months."
  • "And last September, the federal government removed the GST from new rental construction, a move that was matched by some provinces through the suspension of their own sales taxes."
summary:
Summary

Canada faces a severe housing affordability crisis, with RBC reporting a need for 320,000 new housing units annually until 2030—an increase of nearly 50% from current levels. Housing starts decreased to 240,000 in 2023 from 271,000 in 2021 according to figures from Canada Mortgage and Housing Corp. The national benchmark home price is $720,000, up $200,000 since 2020. Ottawa has announced a spate of policy proposals include a $1.5-billion rental fund and a $400-million addition to the Housing Accelerator Fund. Challenges include construction industry capacity, retirement of workers, and material costs. The Bank of Canada may lower interest rates, but this is unlikely to significantly improve affordability.

Facts

Annual housing units needed

  • 50% (increase of 80,000 units from recent levels)

Housing starts

  • -11.4% (decrease of 31,000 from 271,000 in 2021 to 240,000 in 2023)

National benchmark home price

  • $720,000 (increase of $200,000 since the outset of 2020)

Policy proposals

  • $1.5-billion (fund to acquire rental units)
  • $400-million (addition to the $4-billion Housing Accelerator Fund)

Construction industry challenges

  • 20% (of construction workers at or nearing retirement age)

Interest rate expectations

  • Expected decrease (mid-year by the Bank of Canada)

Household formation projection

  • 1.9 million (additional households by 2030)
title: Canada’s housing crisis poised to worsen without major reforms, RBC report says

quotes:
• "Housing affordability is cutting through to government policies on immigration and education and impacting Canada’s reputation and ability to attract talent and investment."
  • "The Federal government’s caps on international students and temporary foreign workers are just some of the recent policy measures announced to address the crisis but it will not shrink housing demand."
  • "If affordability remains close to where it is today, many renters won’t be able to afford rent in the future. "
  • "More than 40% of the one million new households that can’t buy a home by 2030 will also not earn enough to afford rent at the market price."
  • "The drop in mortgage rates alone boosted an average Canadian household’s home purchasing budget by up to 25% (or $133,000) by early 2021, according to our estimates."
  • "Lengthy and costly project approval processes, as well as other regulatory issues (including highly restrictive zoning), fast-rising building costs and labour shortages slowed the supply response [to expand the housing stock]"
  • "Mortgage payments on a typical home on the market came to represent the largest share of household income ever, denying even more middle-income Canadians access to the housing ladder."
  • "However, the downside of significantly cutting immigration would be considerable for Canada’s economy over the long run...Our economic growth potential would be hampered if their departure from the labour force isn’t replaced by newcomers."
  • "The pace of housing construction would need to jump by nearly half in Canada just to meet future demographic growth."
  • "Addressing Canada’s housing needs will largely rest on the ability to significantly expand the stock of housing."
  • "Buyers negatively impacted by higher interest rates, a loss of affordability and growing economic uncertainty is why pre-construction home sales (destined for owner-occupants or condo investors) have plummeted in many parts of Canada (including Ontario) since spring 2022."
  • "One in five construction workers are at or will reach retirement age within the next 10 years. This represents 330,000 workers to replace if they do retire, making it that much harder to expand the [construction] sector’s production capacity."
  • "The rules and regulations governing housing development and construction—often well-meaning when introduced—have accumulated greatly over the years. They now represent a complex and cumbersome set of rules that add tremendous time and costs to projects. Project approval timelines in Canada can be among the lengthiest in the world"
  • "However, more progress is needed and fast. Canada must grow its housing stock like never before, especially at the affordable end of the spectrum in rental and social housing."
  • "Demographic pressures on housing demand may come off the boil, but it won’t entirely subside anytime soon."
  • "Cutting immigration more aggressively would also not instantly restore affordability. It would slow down the growth in housing demand, not shrink it. It would ease upward pressure on home prices and rent only as long as the increase in demand undershoots the expansion of the housing stock—reducing the supply gap."
summary:
Summary

Canada's housing crisis is escalating, with over half of the projected 1.9 million new households by 2030 unable to afford a home. Housing affordability has deteriorated, with ownership costs in two-thirds of urban markets exceeding 35% of median household income - indicating an excessive level. The share of Canadians who can afford to buy a home has shrunk, where 45% of all households would have the income to own a condo and a smaller 26% have enough for a single-detached home at today’s prices and interest rates, down from 61% and 49% respectively 2 decades ago. The rental vacancy rate is at a historical low of 1.5%, and rents have surged. What led to the housing crisis? 1. Number of people struggling to enter the market grew in a decade before the pandemic due to the gov.'s expansive immigration policy, aging population and BoC low rate cuts leading to out of city migration in search of affordable housing. 2. Government aid and low interest rate electrified the market. 3. Irrational buying and selling pushed prices higher as inventory of homes for sale dropped 33% by spring 2021. 4. Border reopening unleased waves of newcomers into an already heated housing and rental market. 5. Aggressive interest rate hikes sparks affordability crisis, increasing the stress in the rental market and affecting home building activities. The BoC rate drop will moderately affect the mortgage rate but affordability is still a significant challenge. Meanwhile the Federal government's measures to cap international students and temporary foreign workers will not significantly reduce housing demand, but only slow down the growth. Homebuilders would have to ramp up production to meet demand to 320,000 annually (from 218,000 avg.), and will need to further improve to see changes in price, but are limited by capacity constraints, especially in the issue of retention and labour shortage. RBC also provides seven recommendations to take on the supply and affordability changes: 1. aggressively expand the construction sector's labour pool by prioritizing construction skills among new immigrants, set ambitious targets for skilled trade school enrolments and incentivizing aging construction workers to remain in their jobs longer. 2. Develop and adopt innovative designs, building techniques and technology. 3. Speed up project approvals. 4. Ease zoning restrictions to make a more productive use of land. 5. Lower the cost of building new housing. 6. Change the mix of housing being built. 7. Expand the housing stock from within existing housing structure and properties. 

Key Points

  • 1 million out of 1.9 million new households by 2030 will not be able to buy a home
  • Homeownership and rent costs hit records:
    • Ownership costs exceed 35% of median household income in two-thirds of urban markets
    • At today's prices and interest rates:
      • only 45% of all households have the income to own a condo
      • only 26% of all households have enough to own a single-detached home
      • down from 61% and 49% 2 decades ago
    • Rental vacancy rate:
      • dropped 1.5% nationwide in 2023, historic low
      • Average rent increase
        • $100 more per month last year
  • What led to the housing crisis:
    • 1. Number of people struggling to enter the market grew in a decade before the pandemic due to the gov.'s expansive immigration policy, aging population and BoC low rate cuts leading to out of city migration in search of affordable housing.
    • 2. Government aid and low interest rate electrified the market.
      • during Covid-19 gov. aid boosted household disposable income to 8.4%
      • with many spending avenues blocked by lockdowns, income gain focus shifted to housing as requirements changed
      • BoC amplified the issue with aggressive monetary policy easing, slashing rates to 0.25% and flooding the market with lliquidity
    • 3.  Irrational buying and selling pushed prices higher as inventory of homes for sale dropped 33% by spring 2021
      • rising market heat attracted more sellers, though not enough to match supercharged demand
      • soaring prices created a sense of urgency adding to the irrationality, as a "fear of missing out" set in
    • 4. Border reopening unleased waves of newcomers into an already heated housing and rental market:
      • flood of temporary foreign workers to ease labour shortages in low-wage service industries
      • flood of international students as tight provincial funding prompted post-secondary institutions to admit more students
      • on top of solid permanent residents growth
      • directed demand mostly into rental market
    • 5. Aggressive interest rate hikes sparks affordability crisis, increasing the stress in the rental market and affecting home building activities
      • impact on home resales activity was immediate - plunging 40% in a year
      • prices fell but only reversed a fraction of the previous 2 year gain
      • Housing starts in Canada fell in 2022 and 2023 by a cumulative 11% (or 31,000 units).
  • Actions already in effect:
    • BoC lowering or rates would help homeowners with moderate mortgage rate drops but affordability is still a significant challenge
    • Gov. actions to reduce immigration through lowering permanent immigration and international student permit targets will not shrink housing demand, but slow down its growth :
      • "would ease upward pressure on home prices and rent only as long as the increase in demand undershoots the expansion of the housing stock—reducing the supply gap"
  • Pace of homebuilding needs to jump to accommodate the future growth in households and to ease the demand pressure in the market to lower prices:
    • construction industry has capacity issues:
      • builders struggle to attract and retain workers 
      • job vacancy rate is "among the highest across Canadian industries" (5.1% in Q3 2023)
      • aging workforce (1 in 5 construction workers will reach retirement age in the next 10 years)
    • high project costs cause of a spike in inflation, high interest rates and labour shortages 
  • 7 RBC recommendations to take on the supply and affordability challenge:
    • 1. aggressively expand the construction sector's labour pool by prioritizing construction skills among new immigrants, set ambitious targets for skilled trade school enrolments and incentivizing aging construction workers to remain in their jobs longer.
      • immigrants with an apprenticeship certificate and non-apprenticeable trades certificate only represent 2.4% between 2016-2021, compared to 9.6% in the 80s
    • 2. Develop and adopt innovative designs, building techniques and technology.
      • takes more workers to build a home than 20 years ago
    • 3. Speed up project approvals.
      • Streamline approval processes
      • legislate timelines for approvals and make bodies accountable for meeting requirements
      • prioritize housing projects with quicker turnaround time
      • reward municipalities that use best practices
      • sharpen conflict resolution mehcanisms
      • slim down and harmonizer building codes
    • 4. Ease zoning restrictions to make a more productive use of land.
      • modernize zoning regulations to allow more density and diverse housing mix
      • ease restrictions against converting commercial properties to residential or mixed-use
    • 5. Lower the cost of building new housing.
      • Allow, and make greater use of cost-effective materials
      • Modulate direct government charges
      • Reduce indirect costs arising from regulation
      • Optimize existing land for best use
    • 6. Change the mix of housing being built
      • Eliminate disincentives to building rental apartment projects
      • Waive development charges for affordable housing projects
      • Use publicly owned land to help affordable housing project economics
      • Grow the student housing stock
      • Avoid rent control
      • Hit the right balance in protecting tenants and landlords
    • 7. Expand the housing stock from within existing housing structure and properties.
      • Reclaiming units from the short-term rental businesses
      • Creating new units out of the existing housing could be done relatively quickly and cost-efficiently
      • Office or other non-residential building conversion holds some potential
      • Over-housed Canadians have rooms to spare
title: The Great Rebuild Seven ways to fix Canada's housing shortage

Summary

Retail sales in January rose to $56.3 billion, marking a 2.5% increase year-over-year. Eleven out of eighteen commodity classes saw higher sales, with the most significant growth in motor vehicles at 7.9%. New and used motor vehicle sales grew by 8.0% and 7.7%, respectively. Additionally, food and beverage sales increased by 4.1%, with packaged food dry goods up by 5.3%. Conversely, sales of automotive and household fuels declined by 7.0%, with a 6.7% drop in automotive fuels sales due to lower prices.

Facts

quotes: "Canadian households and businesses diverted almost 10 million tonnes of waste from landfills in 2022, unchanged compared with 2020" - "Diversion efforts targeting plastic materials have begun through the Canada-wide Action Plan on Zero Plastic Waste to meet the target of zero plastic waste by 2030" - "In 2022, organic waste diverted from landfills surpassed 3 million tonnes, down 3% compared with 2020" - "For the first time, the 2022 Waste Management Survey publishes the quantities of organic material composted by classifying them in a more detailed manner"
summary:
Summary

Canadian households and businesses diverted nearly 10 million tonnes of waste from landfills in 2022 unchanged compared with 2020. Ontario and Quebec diverted the most of all recycled and composted waste in 2022. Plastic waste diversion is challenging, with 367,000 tonnes recycled, 72% from residential sources. Newfoundland and Labrador saw a 25% increase in plastic diversion. Organic waste diversion decreased by 3%, with 77% from residential sources. Detailed reporting in 2022 shows 52% of composted organic waste is food waste, 37% is leaf and yard waste, and 11% is other organic materials. Provinces vary in organic waste composition, with food waste being the majority in several provinces.

Facts

  • Total waste diverted
    • 0% (unchanged from 2020)
    • 10 million tonnes in 2022
  • By province waste diversion:
    • Ontario's waste diversion: 3.4 million tonnes
    • British Columbia: 1.7 million tonnes
    • Quebec's waste diversion: 2.7 million tonnes
  • Waste diverted by type:
    • Plastic waste diverted
      • 367,000 tonnes in 2022
      • 72% from residential sources
    • Organic waste diverted
      • 3 million tonnes in 2022
      • 77% from residential sources
  • Composition of composted organic waste
    • 52% food waste (1.6 million tonnes)
    • 37% leaf and yard waste (1.1 million tonnes)
    • 11% other organic materials (350,000 tonnes)
  • Provincial composition of organic waste
    • Nova Scotia, Alberta: 67% food waste
    • Ontario: 53% food waste
    • Quebec: 49% food waste
    • British Columbia: 48% food waste
    • Manitoba: 70% leaf and yard waste
    • Saskatchewan: 44% leaf and yard waste

Summary

Canadian businesses increased their spending on environmental protection to $26.6 billion in 2021, a 16.3% rise from 2020. Resource management accounted for 60.2% of this, up from 51.0% in 2018. The electric power industry led in resource management expenditures with 69.1% of all resource management expenditures in 2021, while oil and gas extraction topped environmental protection spending with 30.1%. Ontario dominated resource management investments (55.6%), and Alberta led in environmental protection (32.3%). Regulations were the main driver for environmental spending in mining and oil industries, with return on investment cited as the biggest obstacle.

Facts

Summary

Canada is facing a housing crisis with a shortage of affordable rentals. The story of Colleen Frank, a senior, was highlighted as she was evicted from her long-term rental due to "renoviction." Recently Prime Minister Justin Trudeau announced a $1.5-billion rental protection fund to help non-profits buy affordable rental apartments. The U.S. suggests preservation is cheaper than new construction. Canada needs 1.7 million affordable homes, with a loss rate of deeply affordable units at 11 for every one built from 2011 to 2021. Summary

Canadian intelligence reports suggest Chinese officials transferred approximately $250,000 to actors in Canada for potential foreign interference in the 2019 federal election. The funds were distributed through various individuals to conceal their origin. Eleven political candidates and thirteen staff members were implicated or affected, with seven candidates from the Liberal Party and four from the Conservative Party. No criminal investigations were opened by the RCMP for the 2019 or 2021 elections.

    • 0 investigations for 2019 or 2021 elections

quotes: "They warn the common belief that lower rates improve affordability is based on the belief low rates have no impact on demand and thus price." - "The Federal Reserve isn’t the only central bank to warn low rates don’t always improve affordability. Just a few years ago, the Bank of Canada (BoC) explained to analysts that low rates historically haven’t improved affordability. "
summary:
```html

Summary

New research from the Dallas Fed challenges the notion that lower interest rates improve housing affordability. They argue that while lower rates decrease mortgage payments, they also increase demand and house prices, which can reduce affordability. Post-2020, housing affordability declined despite low interest rates. The Fed's research indicates that without rate hikes, house prices would have risen faster, further decreasing affordability. They also model scenarios showing that rate cuts aimed at stimulating the economy can slow affordability improvements due to increased demand and house prices.

Facts

  • Housing Affordability Index (HAI)
    • Decrease after 2020
  • Interest Rates
    • Slashed to nearly zero post-Global Financial Crisis
    • Raised early 2022
  • Home Prices
    • 7.5% decrease with a 1 point increase in short-term interest rates over two years
  • Affordability
    • Decline without rate hikes after 2022
    • Improvements slow with rate cuts due to stimulated demand
```
title: Lower Rates Do Not Improve Housing Affordability: US Federal Reserve

Summary

Canadian employment decreased by 2k in March, with the unemployment rate rising to 6.1%, a 0.3 percentage point increase from February and 1.3 points from the post-pandemic low. This rise is attributed to longer job search times, particularly among students, and a 40% increase in layoffs from the previous year. Hours worked also fell by 0.3%, suggesting a potential slowdown in GDP growth. Wage growth remains strong at 5.1% year-over-year, although business surveys indicate it may slow down. The Bank of Canada may consider interest rate cuts by mid-year in response to these trends.

  • Hours worked
    • -0.3% (from February)

Summary

Employment in March saw a minimal decrease of 2,200 jobs, with the employment rate declining by 0.1 percentage points to 61.4%. The unemployment rate increased by 0.3 percentage points to 6.1%, with a year-over-year rise of 1.0 percentage points. Youth employment dropped by 28,000 jobs, while core-aged men saw an increase of 20,000 jobs. Industries such as accommodation and food services, wholesale and retail trade, and professional, scientific and technical services experienced employment declines. Conversely, health care and social assistance saw an increase of 40,000 jobs. Regionally, Quebec, Saskatchewan, and Manitoba faced employment drops, while Ontario reported a rise. Average hourly wages increased by 5.1% year-over-year.

Facts

  • Unemployment rate:  +0.3%, to 6.1%
    • YoY: +1.0%
  • Employment rate:  -0.1%, to 61.4%

quotes: "Graduation of High School Students in British Columbia from 2010/2011 to 2018/2019: A Focus on Special Needs Status" - "Students with special needs (excluding students with gifted status) were less likely to graduate high school." - "For example, students with learning disabilities (about 9 in 10) and those with sensory needs (about 8 to 9 in 10) were most likely to graduate from high school, while students with intellectual disabilities (6 to 7 in 10) were least likely." - "The largest age differences were observed among students with ASD, behavioural needs or mental illness, and physical needs." - "After accounting for individual characteristics, family background and academic achievement, students with gifted status were more likely to graduate from high school than those without special needs." - "Conversely, compared with students without special needs, those with intellectual disabilities had the lowest high school graduation proportions, followed by those with behavioural or mental illness and those with physical needs."
summary:
```html

Summary

The study examined high school graduation rates in British Columbia from 2010/2011 to 2018/2019, focusing on students with special needs. It found significant diversity in graduation rates among different special needs categories. Students with learning disabilities and sensory needs had the highest graduation rates (around 80-90%), while those with intellectual disabilities had the lowest (60-70%). Males were predominant in special needs categories except for gifted students. Graduation rates increased with age, especially for students with special needs. After adjusting for various factors, students with gifted status were more likely to graduate than their peers without special needs.

Facts

  • Male students with special needs (excluding gifted)
    • 80% (ASD category)
  • Graduation rates for students with special needs
    • 90% (learning disabilities)
    • 80-90% (sensory needs)
    • 60-70% (intellectual disabilities)
  • Graduation rates at age 19 compared to age 18 or younger
    • 5-10 percentage points higher (students with special needs)
    • 3-7 percentage points higher (students without special needs)
  • Graduation likelihood after accounting for individual characteristics, family background, and academic achievement
    • Higher (students with gifted status compared to those without special needs)
    • Lowest (students with intellectual disabilities)
```
title: Study: High school graduation in British Columbia from 2010/2011 to 2018/2019: A focus on special needs status

summary:
Summary

Patients in Canada are experiencing longer wait times for priority procedures like hip and knee replacements and cancer surgeries post-COVID-19, despite an increase in the number of surgeries performed. The Canadian Institute for Health Information reports a decline in the percentage of patients treated within recommended time frames since 2019. Disparities exist among provinces, with Ontario generally having shorter waits. Median wait times for certain cancer surgeries have also increased slightly. Strategies such as same-day discharges and hiring more physician assistants are suggested to improve efficiency.

Facts

Summary

Canadian M&A activity in Q1 2024 declined by 23% year-over-year to US$28.1 billion, falling 55% below the 10-year average. Stock sales rebounded to $5 billion from last year's $1.9 billion, yet remained below the $10.1 billion decade average. Debt deals rose by 35%, exceeding the 10-year average by 28%. No IPOs occurred, continuing 2023's downturn. Optimism is seen in equity and debt markets, with expectations of increased M&A activity as recession fears wane and private equity pressure to invest grows.

Facts

  • M&A activity
    • -23% (US$28.1-billion from Q1 2023)
    • -55% (below 10-year Q1 average of US$62.1-billion)

    • -50% (below 10-year average of $10.1-billion)

    • +35% (to $21.4-billion from start of 2023)

    • 0 (no IPOs in Q1 2024)

title: Canadian deal-making still stuck in a rut, despite the hot markets

quotes: "The satellite-derived data, produced by researchers at the University of Maryland, showed that the swaths of forest burned in Canada in 2023 represented one of the largest anomalies witnessed since they began collecting the data globally in 2001. They dubbed it the world’s “most concerning fire story” of the year." - "The surface area burned across Canada last year “is three, four and five times greater than any individual preceding year,” said Matthew Hansen, a remote sensing scientist who leads a lab at the university that studies changes on the Earth’s surface" - "Canada’s overall forest loss last year, though widely described as record-breaking, had only a negligible impact on the country’s vast overall forest cover."
summary:
Summary

Canada experienced a record forest loss of 8.6 million hectares in 2023, with over 90% due to wildfires. This figure is 3-5 times higher than any previous year and represents more than 2% of Canada's total forest cover. The World Resources Institute highlighted this as the most concerning fire story globally. Despite the significant loss, Canada's overall forest area is expected to remain stable. The federal government reported an even higher area burned at 15 million hectares. Globally, tropical forests decreased by 3.7 million hectares, with deforestation rates dropping in Brazil and Colombia but rising in other countries.

Facts

  • Canada's forest loss in 2023
    • 8.6 million hectares
  • Percentage due to wildfires
    • Over 90%
  • Comparison to previous years
    • 3-5 times greater
  • Total forest cover of Canada
    • 367 million hectares (end of 2022)
  • Percentage of total forest cover burned
    • More than 2%
  • Average area burned annually over the past 50 years
    • 2.3 million hectares
  • Previous record for area burned (1989)
    • 7.6 million hectares
  • Canadian federal government's reported area burned in 2023
    • 15 million hectares
  • Global tropical forest loss in 2023
    • 3.7 million hectares
  • Deforestation rates in Brazil and Colombia
    • Decreased significantly
  • Deforestation rates in Laos, Bolivia, DRC, and Nicaragua
    • Accelerating losses
  • 2030 target for halting forest loss
    • Far off track
title: Canada lost 8.6 million hectares of forest in 2023, more than 90% due to wildfires

quotes: "A law known as Bill 7 enacted in 2022 has garnered much criticism for allowing people to be placed in a long-term care home not of their choosing, but AdvantAge Ontario CEO Lisa Levin said the law has had other consequences as well." - "Levin, of AdvantAge Ontario, said it seems like the impact on cultural home admissions was an unintended consequence of Bill 7 and she has had “encouraging” conversations with Minister Stan Cho about how to address it."
summary:
```html

Summary

In Toronto, cultural long-term care homes like Villa Colombo and Ivan Franko Home face challenges due to Bill 7, enacted in 2022. This law prioritizes hospital patients needing long-term care, leading to non-Italian residents being admitted to Italian-speaking homes, causing cultural isolation and confusion. At Ivan Franko Home, non-Ukrainian occupancy has risen to 25% from 8-10% pre-pandemic, necessitating additional cultural accommodations. Hospitals can charge patients $400 per day for refusing transfers. Discussions are ongoing to address these unintended consequences.

Facts

Bill 7 - Enacted in 2022 - Prioritizes hospital patients for long-term care home placement Non-Italian residents in Villa Colombo - Increase of 3 residents per month Non-Ukrainian residents in Ivan Franko Home - Increase to 25% occupancy - Pre-pandemic occupancy was 8-10% Hospital transfer refusal fee - $400 per day Transfer distance for patients - Up to 70 kilometres in general - Up to 150 kilometres in northern Ontario ```
title: Cultural LTC admissions drying up in Ontario due to new priority rules

Ford Motor Co. announced a delay in launching electric vehicles at its Oakville, Ontario plant until 2027, two years later than planned. Summary

Canada's merchandise exports and imports saw a significant rise in February, with exports increasing by 5.8% and imports by 4.6%. This led to a trade surplus expansion from $608 million in January to $1.4 billion in February. Exports were driven by a record $2.0 billion (68.8%) increase in unwrought gold, contributing to over half of the export growth. Imports reached a peak since June 2023, with a notable 9.7% rise in electronic and electrical equipment and parts. Trade with the United States resulted in a surplus increase to $9.1 billion, while the deficit with other countries narrowed to $7.7 billion.

quotes: "Prime Minister Justin Trudeau, announcing billions of dollars in federal funding Wednesday to bolster apartment construction, says he will bypass provinces that don’t want to work with his government on the issue." - "“If a province decides it doesn’t want to be ambitious on housing, that’s their decision. We’ll work with the municipalities within that province that are ambitious.”" - "“I’m going to leave that up to each municipality to decide. They know best,” said Mr. Ford, referring to decisions on housing policy" - "“I don’t believe in forcing municipalities. I believe in working with municipalities,” said the former Toronto city councilor." - "In a statement sent out late Tuesday, the Alberta government said it had “deep concerns” about the federal housing announcement." - "“This is another example of the federal government’s long history of ignoring the province’s jurisdiction and playing politics with important issues like housing,” said the joint statement from Jason Nixon, Minister of Seniors, Community, and Social Services, and Minister of Municipal Affairs Ric McIver." - "Also Tuesday, the Quebec government rejected the federal plan, with the province’s ministers of Canadian relations and housing saying the Trudeau government should tackle the housing problem by addressing issues of federal responsibility such as immigration."
summary:
Summary

Prime Minister Justin Trudeau announced an additional $15 billion for an apartment construction loan program, aiming to create at least 30,000 new units. This funding is part of a series of housing initiatives, including a $6 billion infrastructure program. Trudeau emphasized working directly with municipalities if provinces are not cooperative. Ontario's Premier Doug Ford expressed willingness to collaborate but rejected forcing policies on municipalities. Alberta and Quebec criticized the federal approach, citing jurisdictional concerns and other priorities. Saskatchewan questioned the relevance of multiplexes for their province.

Facts

    • + $15 billion
    • Minimum 30,000 new units
  • Ontario's response
    • $6 billion infrastructure program acknowledged
    • Emphasis on municipal decision-making

      • $625-million for water-systems fund

    • Call for federal action on immigration

    • Concerns about impact on other infrastructure projects
  • Canada Builds program conditions
    • Provincial and territorial partnerships
    • Complementary provincial investments

Summary

Canada's federal government plans to reduce non-permanent resident arrivals, aiming to lower their population share to 5% from 6.5%. This policy may slow GDP growth by 0.5% by 2025 but won't significantly affect per-capita GDP, unemployment, inflation, or interest rates. An older population and lower labour force participation are expected, potentially easing housing demand but not solving long-term supply issues. The number of non-permanent residents needs to decline by 20% (500,000 people) over three years. Immigration helps mitigate population aging, with 70% of new permanent residents under 35, compared to 40% of Canadians.

Facts

  • Share of temporary resident population
    • -1.5% (from 6.5% to 5%)
  • Non-permanent resident population reduction
    • -20% (500,000 fewer people)
  • GDP growth reduction by 2025
    • -0.5%
  • Labour force participation rate (2021)
    • Non-permanent residents: 74.2%
    • Broader Canadian population: 65.6%
  • Age distribution of new permanent residents
    • Under 35: 70%
  • Age distribution of Canadian population
    • Under 35: 40%
  • New home starts vs. population increase (last year)
    • New home starts: 242,000
    • Population increase: 1.2 million (approx. 360k new households)
```
title: How lowering the number of non-permanent residents will impact Canada’s economy

quotes: "A household earning a median income needed to spend a staggering 63.5% of it to cover the costs of owning an average home at market price." - "We estimate they’ve shrunk the maximum budget for a household with a median income by 22% since the first quarter of 2022 to just under $500,000." - "It’s never been as expensive to own a home anywhere, anytime in Canada as it was in Vancouver in the fourth quarter." - "RBC’s aggregate affordability measure reached its worst level ever in the fourth quarter (84.8%)." - "RBC’s aggregate measure reached 49.9% in the fourth quarter—a record high for the area." - "RBC’s aggregate affordability measure was at a record high of 53.3% in the fourth quarter, a level limiting the pool of potential buyers." - "RBC’s aggregate measure jumped to 45.3% in the fourth quarter—far exceeding the long-run average of 31.9%."
summary:
Summary

Canadian homeownership costs soared in Q4 2023, with a median household needing to spend 63.5% of income on an average home, up from 61.8% in Q3. Mortgage payments rose 3.3% to $3,990 despite a 0.5% price drop. Affordability worsened across all markets, with Vancouver, Victoria, and Toronto hit hardest. The Bank of Canada's rate hikes since March 2022 reduced median household purchasing power by 22% to under $500,000. Prospects for affordability improvement hinge on anticipated mid-year rate cuts, but significant challenges persist, and a full recovery is expected to be slow.

Facts

Ownership costs as a percentage of median income

- Increased to 63.5% (up 1.7 percentage points) Monthly mortgage payment -

Rose by 3.3% ($125 increase) Composite home price - Decreased by 0.5% Median household maximum budget - Decreased by 22% (down to just under $500,000) Home prices - Fell by 1.8% Affordability measure in Victoria - Increased by 4.0 percentage points to 80.2% Affordability measure in Vancouver - Reached 106.4% Affordability measure in Calgary - Worsened to 48.3% Affordability measure in Edmonton - Increased to 36.8% Affordability measure in Saskatoon - Rose by 1.6 percentage points to 37.8% Affordability measure in Regina - Stood at 30.4% Affordability measure in Winnipeg - Rose to 32.8% Affordability measure in Toronto - Reached 84.8% Affordability measure in Ottawa - Reached 49.9% Affordability measure in Montreal - Was at 53.3% Affordability measure in Quebec City - Stood at 35.7% Affordability measure in Saint John - Rose by 1.3 percentage points to 31.4% Affordability measure in Halifax - Jumped to 45.3% Affordability measure in St. John's - Was at 28.7%
title: Toughest time ever to afford a home as soaring interest costs keep raising the bar

Business sentiment and sales growth expectations have stabilized, with demand remaining weak but showing signs of optimism. In Canada, 42% of people aged 15 and older provided unpaid care in 2022, with 13% caring for both children and adults, making them "sandwich caregivers." Summary

Real GDP of non-profit institutions marginally increased by 0.1% in Q4, following a 0.8% rise in Q3. Non-profits serving households and businesses saw growths of 1.1% and 0.9% respectively, while those serving governments declined by 0.2%. Annually, real GDP of non-profits rose 2.7% in 2023. Job numbers in non-profits increased by 0.8% in Q4, with health care jobs up by 1.4% and social services by 2.6%. Nominal GDP of non-profits grew by 0.8% in Q4, contributing to an 8.3% share of the economy-wide nominal GDP.

Summary

In 2022, Canadian farms saw average operating revenues increase by 10.1% to $707,635, while expenses rose by 13.6% to $576,003, leading to a 2.9% decrease in net operating income to $131,632. Oilseed and grain farms had the highest profit margin at 28.3%, despite a decline due to rising expenses. Potato farms followed with a 22.9% margin. Livestock revenues grew by 10.0%, with hog farms having the highest revenues at $3.4 million. Over half of Canada's farm revenues were generated by the Prairie provinces, with oilseed and grain farms contributing $33.9 billion.

Facts

  • Average operating revenues
    • 10.1% ($707,635)
  • Average operating expenses
    • 13.6% ($576,003)
  • Average net operating income
    • -2.9% ($131,632)
  • Oilseed and grain farms profit margin
    • 28.3 cents per dollar
  • Potato farms profit margin
    • 22.9 cents per dollar
  • Livestock sector operating revenues
    • 10.0% ($47.9 billion)
  • Hog farms operating revenues
    • $3.4 million
  • Prairie provinces total farm revenues
    • 56.2% ($60.9 billion)
  • Saskatchewan oilseed and grain revenue proportion
    • 79.7%
  • Saskatchewan operating profit margin
    • 26.2 cents per dollar
  • Beef cattle farms revenues in the Prairies
    • $16.1 billion

summary:
Summary

Temporary foreign workers (TFWs) in Canadian primary agriculture have low transition rates to permanent residency (PR), with only 10% obtaining PR after five years and 16.8% after ten years. Transition rates are lower for lower-skilled occupations and those under the Seasonal Agricultural Worker Program (SAWP). Retention in agriculture post-PR is also low, with only around one-fifth remaining after five years. Over 60% move to other industries, and retention rates vary by skill level, program stream, and agricultural subsector. The study suggests that PR status for TFWs may not address the labor shortage in agriculture.

Facts

Transition to PR after 5 years - 10% (slightly more than 10%) Transition to PR after 10 years - 16.8% Transition rates by skill level (2005-2009 cohort, after 10 years) - Higher skill: 60.9% - Lower skill: 11.5% Transition rates by program (2005-2009 cohort, after 10 years) - SAWP: 5.9% - Other agricultural streams: Higher than SAWP - Other TFWPs and IMP: Higher than other agricultural streams Retention in agriculture after 1 year of PR - 50% or less Retention in agriculture after 5 years of PR - Around 20% Movement to other industries after 5 years of PR - More than 60% No T4 Statement of Remuneration Paid after PR - Significant portion Retention by skill level (2006-2010 cohort, after 5 years of PR) - Lower skill: 16.0% - Higher skill: 26.5% Retention by program (2006-2010 cohort, after 5 years of PR) - SAWP: 19.3% (PR admission year), 80.0% moved to another industry (after 5 years) - Other agricultural TFWPs: 33.0% (after 5 years) Retention by subsector (2006-2010 cohort, after PR admission year) - Crop production: 49.7% - Animal production: 81.5%
title: Temporary foreign workers in primary agriculture in Canada: Transition from temporary residency to permanent residency and industry retention after transition

quotes: "GARs who were assigned to smaller communities, compared with those assigned to large cities, were much more likely to move" - "those assigned to Toronto had the lowest employment incidence and annual earnings" - "those who chose to move to gateway cities had the lowest employment incidence and annual earnings" - "those who moved to a smaller city tended to report stronger labour market outcomes" - "the majority (89%) of these differences across city size could be explained by the city’s employment rate, as well as the source region of GARs" - "GARs from West Asia had the lowest employment incidence" - "GARs from South America had the highest employment incidence" - "employed GARs had lower annual earnings than PSRs and economic class and family class immigrants" - "GARs who moved down in city size tended to have better economic outcomes than other movers" - "differences in individual sociodemographic characteristics and city-level characteristics accounted for the majority (89%) of the observed differences in employment incidence" - "regional economic conditions should be an integral part of GAR resettlement decisions" - "strong economic outcomes can be achieved in smaller communities, which can in turn increase retention rates"
summary:
Summary

The study analyzed economic outcomes of government-assisted refugees (GARs) in Canada, comparing those who stayed in their designated cities to those who moved. GARs in smaller cities had higher employment and earnings than those in larger cities like Toronto. Movers to smaller cities also reported better outcomes. Differences in employment incidence (89%) and earnings (47%) between Toronto stayers and others were largely explained by the city's employment rate and GARs' source region. The study suggests that economic integration is more successful in smaller communities for those who stay.

Facts

  • Employment incidence of GAR stayers in Toronto after 5 years: 49%
    • -14.6 percentage points (compared to medium-sized CMAs)
    • -23.0 percentage points (compared to small urban communities)
  • Employment incidence of GAR movers to gateway cities after 5 years: ~50%
    • +15 percentage points (compared to those moving to smaller communities)
  • Annual earnings of GAR stayers in Toronto after 5 years: $19,500
    • -$6,500 (compared to medium-sized CMAs)
    • -$7,500 (compared to small urban communities)
  • Annual earnings of GAR movers to gateway cities after 5 years: ~$21,000
    • -$5,200 (compared to those moving to medium-sized CMAs)
  • Percentage of GARs moving from their intended destination after 10 years: 42%
    • +23 percentage points (compared to family class immigrants)
  • Control variables explained employment incidence gap: 89%
    • Source region and city employment rate as key factors
  • Control variables explained annual earnings gap: 47%
    • Source region and city employment rate as significant contributors
title: Economic outcomes of government-assisted refugees in designated destinations: The effect of city size

summary:
Summary

In recent years, the Provincial Nominee Program (PNP) has become the primary route for economic immigrants entering Canada, with significant provincial variation. In 2019, 35% of economic immigrants were PNPs, which rose back to 35% in 2022 after a dip to 24% in 2021 due to the pandemic. The PNP's importance varied, being nearly the sole source in Manitoba and Saskatchewan, while less significant in Ontario. There was a substantial increase in provincial nominees with Canadian work or study experience, improving economic outcomes. Intended occupations varied, with more skilled and technical nominees in some provinces and more professionals in others

Facts

  • Provincial Nominee Program (PNP) entries
    • 1999: 500 immigrants
    • 2004: 6,000 immigrants
    • 2019: 68,000 immigrants
    • 2022: 88,300 immigrants
  • Percentage of economic immigrants through PNP
    • 2019: 35%
    • 2021: 24% (due to COVID-19)
    • 2022: 35%
  • Pre-landing Canadian work experience
    • 2000: 6% of provincial nominees
    • 2019: 61% of provincial nominees
    • 2020: 67% of provincial nominees
    • 2021: 72% of provincial nominees
  • Pre-landing Canadian study experience
    • 2000: 4% of provincial nominees
    • 2019: 38% of provincial nominees
    • 2020: 40% of provincial nominees
    • 2021: 44% of provincial nominees
  • Intended occupations of provincial nominees (2019)
    • Skilled and technical: Dominant in Nova Scotia, Saskatchewan, Alberta
    • Professional and managerial: More prevalent in British Columbia, New Brunswick, Prince Edward Island
    • Lower-skilled: Majority in Manitoba
  • Age at landing (2019)
    • 20 to 29 years old: Increased from 24% in 2005 to 38%
    • 40 to 54 years old: Decreased from 38% in 2005 to 21%
  • Source regions of provincial nominees (2019)
    • Southern Asia: 34% to 42% depending on the province
  • Language spoken at landing
    • 2009-2010: 5% to 32% spoke neither English nor French
    • 2019: Almost all spoke English or French
title: The Provincial Nominee Program: Provincial differences

quotes: "Young Canadians recently reported that they are less satisfied and less hopeful about the future" - "In 2022, concerns over rising prices led about one third of youth to reconsider buying a home or moving to a new rental" - "Canada has the highest household debt to disposable income ratio in the G7, at 185% compared with an average of 125% for all G7 countries" - "Younger households are starting to turn away from the housing market, as their overall mortgage balances have declined in recent quarters" - "Households where the primary earner is under 35 years of age were the only age cohort to reduce their mortgage burden" - "The disposable income of young households rose by 2.5%, reflecting broad-based wage increases, while their average net saving rose 9.2%" - "The household debt-to-income ratio of young households fell to 165.2% in the third quarter of 2023, about 10 percentage points below its level during the same quarter in 2022" - "Young households spent 10 cents of every dollar earned towards servicing their debt, up from around 7 cents in 2022" - "Housing assets account for 89% of their total wealth, making them more exposed to fluctuations in the real estate market" - "The gap between perceptions of inflation and actual inflation is unusually wide, particularly for young Canadians" - "People living in a rented dwelling (41.3%) were more likely to be experiencing difficulties meeting their financial needs than homeowners with a mortgage (35.5%) or without a mortgage (20.4%)" - "Down-payment gifts have become increasingly important for first time home buyers" - "In 2021, the share of first-time buyers that received help from family members was just under 30%, up from 20% in 2015; during this period, the value of the average gift rose from $52,000 to $82,000"
summary:
```html

Summary

Young Canadian households are increasingly avoiding the housing market due to high debt-to-income ratios and rising costs. The national household debt to disposable income ratio is at 185%, with young households under 35 reducing their mortgage burden. Despite a 2.5% increase in disposable income and a 9.2% rise in net saving for young households in 2023, their debt-to-income ratio decreased to 165.2%. Housing remains a key wealth source, comprising 89% of young families' wealth. Economic pressures and affordability issues threaten socio-economic mobility, with more first-time home buyers relying on family gifts for down payments.

Facts

  • Household debt to disposable income ratio
    • 185% (Canada's ratio)
    • 125% (G7 average)
  • Mortgage balances
    • - (Young households reduced mortgage debt)
    • $73 billion (Total mortgage liabilities growth year-over-year in Q3 2023)
  • Disposable income
    • 2.5% (Increase for young households in 2023)
  • Net saving
    • 9.2% (Increase for young households in 2023)
  • Debt-to-income ratio
    • 165.2% (Young households in Q3 2023)
    • -10 percentage points (Decrease from Q3 2022)
  • Debt service ratio
    • 2.4 percentage points (Increase to 9.7% for young households in 2023)
  • Housing wealth
    • 55% (Overall household wealth from real estate)
    • 89% (Young families' wealth from housing assets)
  • Down-payment gifts
    • 30% (Share of first-time buyers receiving gifts in 2021)
    • 20% (Share in 2015)
    • $52,000 to $82,000 (Average gift value increase from 2015 to 2021)
```
title: Housing, wealth and debt: How are young Canadians adapting to current financial and housing pressures?

Summary

Canada's population reached 40,769,890 on January 1, 2024, a 3.2% increase from the previous year, mainly due to temporary immigration. Permanent immigration accounted for 471,771 people, while non-permanent residents (NPRs) increased by 804,901. Alberta experienced the largest net gain from interprovincial migration, with 55,107 people. Ontario saw the largest net loss to other provinces at 36,197 people. In the fourth quarter of 2023, the population grew by 0.6%, with 100,472 permanent immigrants and an increase of 150,347 NPRs.

Facts

  • Fertility Rate

  • Population Growth (2023)

  • Interprovincial Migration (2023)

  • Alberta's Net Gain from Interprovincial Migration (2023)
    • +55,107 people
  • Ontario's Net Loss to Other Provinces (2023)
    • -36,197 people
  • Population Growth in Fourth Quarter (2023)
    • +0.6% (+241,494 people)
  • Permanent Immigrants in Fourth Quarter (2023)

summary:
Summary

Tourism spending in Canada increased by 2.3% in Q4 2023 and 13.5% annually. Tourism GDP grew by 2.5% in Q4 and 9.5% over the year. Passenger air transport and accommodation services led the growth in spending, while pre-trip expenses declined. Tourism's share of GDP remained at 1.58%. Jobs in tourism rose by 0.7% in Q4, with the sector's share of total jobs at 3.34%. International visitor spending grew by 3.3%, with accommodation and food services leading. Domestic tourism spending rose by 2.0% in Q4 and 7.7% annually, with air transport being the main contributor.

Young Canadians are adapting to housing market pressures with mortgage balances for those under 35 decreasing, despite a general increase of $73 billion in Q3 2023. quotes: "Canada"s population reached 40,769,890 inhabitants, which corresponds to an increase of 1,271,872 people compared with January 1, 2023" - "This was the highest annual population growth rate (+3.2%) in Canada since 1957 (+3.3%)" - "Most of Canada"s 3.2% population growth rate stemmed from temporary immigration in 2023" - "Without temporary immigration, Canada"s population growth would have been almost three times less (+1.2%)" - "In 2023, the vast majority (97.6%) of Canada"s population growth came from international migration" - "471,771 permanent immigrants made Canada their home" - "A further 804,901 non-permanent residents (NPRs) were added to Canada"s population in 2023" - "It is estimated that 2,661,784 NPRs were living in Canada on January 1, 2024" - "Alberta saw the largest net gain in interprovincial migration in 2023, adding 55,107 people" - "This was the largest gain in interprovincial migration nationally since comparable data became available in 1972" - "Ontario lost the greatest number of people to other provinces and territories in 2023, following a loss of 38,816 people in 2022" - "Canada"s population increased by 241,494 people (+0.6%)" - "This was the highest rate of growth in a fourth quarter since 1956 (+0.7%)" - "Canada welcomed 100,472 permanent immigrants in the fourth quarter of 2023"
summary:
```html

Summary

Canada's population reached 40,769,890 on January 1, 2024, marking a 3.2% increase from the previous year, the highest since 1957. This growth was primarily due to international migration, accounting for 97.6% of the increase. Permanent immigration added 471,771 people, while temporary immigration contributed 804,901 non-permanent residents (NPRs). Interprovincial migration saw 333,000 Canadians relocate, with Alberta gaining the most. The fourth quarter of 2023 experienced a 0.6% population growth, with 100,472 permanent immigrants and an increase of 150,347 NPRs.

Facts

  • Fertility Rate
    • 1.33 children per woman (2022)
  • Population Growth Rate (2023)
    • +3.2% (+1,271,872 people)
  • Population Growth Without Temporary Immigration
    • +1.2%
  • Permanent Immigrants (2023)
    • +471,771 people
  • Non-Permanent Residents (2023)
    • +804,901 people
  • Interprovincial Migration (2023)
    • 333,000 Canadians moved
  • Alberta's Net Gain from Interprovincial Migration (2023)
    • +55,107 people
  • Ontario's Net Loss to Interprovincial Migration (2023)
    • -36,197 people
  • Population Growth in Fourth Quarter (2023)
    • +0.6% (+241,494 people)
  • Permanent Immigrants in Fourth Quarter (2023)
    • +100,472 people
  • Quebec's Decrease in New Immigrants in Fourth Quarter
    • -46.7% (-7,561 people from 16,188 to 8,627)
  • Increase of NPRs from October 1, 2023, to January 1, 2024
    • +150,347 people
```
title: Canada's population estimates: Strong population growth in 2023

quotes: "Almost two-thirds of children with long-term conditions or disabilities use centre-based child care as their main child care arrangement" - "Over one-third of children who receive support services or therapies get them in child care"
summary:
Summary

In 2023, 62% of Canadian children aged 0 to 5 with long-term conditions or disabilities were in child care, with 69% using centre-based care. Comparatively, 56% of all children in this age group were in care, with 61% in centre-based care. Of the children with conditions or disabilities in care, 56% received support services or therapies, and 35% of these received services within their child care. Additionally, 61% needed extra support for activities, with the highest needs in social interactions (32%) and managing behaviour (30%). Most parents felt their child's needs were met in their care arrangements.

Facts

  • Centre-based child care usage
    • 69% (children with conditions/disabilities)

    • 21% (all children aged 0 to 5)
  • Home-based child care usage
    • 12% (children with conditions/disabilities)
    • 16% (all children aged 0 to 5)
  • Support services or therapies received

    • 35% (received within child care)
  • Extra support needed

    • 29% (communicating)

quotes: "The expansion of the Provincial Nominee Program has significantly transformed the selection process for economic immigrants in Canada since the early 2000s" - "The Provincial Nominee Program has played a key role in bringing economic immigrants to the Atlantic and Prairie provinces" - "The sociodemographic characteristics of provincial nominees have also changed considerably" - "The growth in the PNP, combined with the corresponding decline in the FSWP, has affected the distribution of intended occupations among economic immigrants" - "There was also significant provincial variation in the intended occupations of new provincial nominees in 2019" - "Provincial nominees used to earn more in the initial years after immigration than FSWP immigrants, but this pattern has changed for subsequent arrival cohorts"
summary:
```html

Summary

The Provincial Nominee Program (PNP) has become the predominant route for economic immigrants to Canada, with its share increasing from negligible in 2000 to 40% in 2023. The program has significantly influenced the distribution of immigrants across provinces, with a notable increase in the Prairie and Atlantic provinces. The PNP has also altered the demographics and occupations of immigrants, with a rise in those previously working as temporary foreign workers and in technical occupations. However, recent cohorts of provincial nominees have seen lower initial earnings compared to Federal Skilled Worker Program (FSWP) immigrants.

Facts

  • FSWP share of economic immigrants
    • -66% (from 79% in 2000 to 13% in 2023)
  • PNP share of economic immigrants
    • +40% (in 2023)
  • PNP share in Saskatchewan
    • 93% (in 2023)
  • PNP share in Manitoba
    • 85% (in 2023)
  • PNP share in Ontario
    • 21% (in 2023)
  • Immigrants intending to settle in Prairie and Atlantic provinces
    • +23% (from 10% in 2000 to 33% in 2023)
  • Immigrants intending to settle in Ontario
    • -23% (from 61% in 2000 to 38% in 2023)
  • Provincial nominees aged 20 to 54 previously temporary foreign workers
    • +55% (from 6% in 2000 to 61% in 2019)
  • Provincial nominees in Alberta previously temporary foreign workers
    • 85% (in 2019)
  • Provincial nominees in New Brunswick previously temporary foreign workers
    • 28% (in 2019)
  • Provincial nominees in Saskatchewan previously temporary foreign workers
    • 35% (in 2019)
  • Earnings difference between provincial nominees and FSWP immigrants (2005-to-2014 cohort)
    • +$6,900 (in 2020 dollars, initial two years after admission)
  • Earnings difference between provincial nominees and FSWP immigrants (2015-to-2019 cohort)
    • -$6,500 (initial two years after admission)
```
title: The expansion and changing characteristics of the Provincial Nominee Program

quotes: "The 2021 Census of Population results showed that most racialized groups generally have higher levels of education than the total population in Canada." - "The proportion of racialized individuals aged 25 to 64 with no certificate, diploma or degree dropped from 13.0% in 2006 to 9.0% in 2021." - "The proportion of racialized people aged 25 to 64 with a bachelor"s degree or higher rose from 34.9% in 2006 to 47.5% in 2021, reaching a new high." - "For the first time, in 2021, the proportion of racialized women with a bachelor"s degree or higher outpaced the proportion of their male counterparts." - "In 2021, more than half (55.8%) of racialized individuals aged 25 to 64 who recently immigrated to Canada (during the period from 2011 to 2021) had a bachelor"s degree or higher."
summary:
```html

Summary

Racialized groups in Canada have seen significant educational attainment improvements from 2006 to 2021. The proportion of racialized individuals aged 25 to 64 without any certificate, diploma, or degree decreased from 13.0% to 9.0%, while those with a bachelor's degree or higher increased from 34.9% to 47.5%. Southeast Asian women had the largest decrease in the proportion without qualifications (-9.2 percentage points). Racialized women surpassed men in bachelor's degree attainment in 2021 (48.4% vs. 46.5%). Recent immigrants (2011-2021) are more educated, with 55.8% holding at least a bachelor's degree.

Facts

  • No certificate, diploma, or degree (2006-2021)
    • -4.0 percentage points (13.0% to 9.0%)
    • Total population: -5.5 percentage points (15.4% to 9.9%)
    • Southeast Asian women: -9.2 percentage points (31.2% to 22.0%)
    • Southeast Asian men: -4.2 percentage points (25.4% to 21.2%)
  • Bachelor's degree or higher (2006-2021)
    • +12.6 percentage points (34.9% to 47.5%)
    • Total population: +9.9 percentage points (23.0% to 32.9%)
    • South Asian: +18.7 percentage points (36.5% to 55.2%)
    • Korean: +6.3 percentage points (54.2% to 60.5%)
    • Black: +12.5 percentage points (19.9% to 32.4%)
    • Southeast Asian: +10.6 percentage points (19.9% to 30.5%)
  • Racialized women vs. men (2006-2021)
    • Women: +15.8 percentage points (32.6% to 48.4%)
    • Men: +9.1 percentage points (37.4% to 46.5%)
  • Recent immigrants' education (2011-2021)
    • 53.2% under economic category
    • Recent immigrants: 58.0% under economic category
    • Before 2011: 50.8% under economic category
    • Recent racialized immigrants with bachelor's or higher: 55.8%
    • Racialized immigrants before 2011 with bachelor's or higher: 41.5%
    • Recent South Asian immigrants with bachelor's or higher: 68.6%
    • South Asian immigrants before 2011 with bachelor's or higher: 44.8%
```
title: Statistics on social inclusion for ethnocultural groups in Canada: New products and selected results on the evolution of education among racialized groups, 2006 to 2021

quotes: "In January, aircraft movements at Canada"s major and select small airports totalled 317,569, down 5.9% from January 2023." - " "Local movements fell 15.7% year over year to 79,012, while itinerant movements declined 2.1% to 238,557." - " "Major Canadian airlines flew 6.8 million passengers on scheduled and charter services in January 2024, with the passenger load factor at 83.1%." - " "In January, other international traffic (outside the United States) was up 14.7% year over year, reaching 18,646 movements, and remains above the pre-COVID-19 pandemic level." - " "Transborder movements to and from the United States were up 3.3% to 32,133 in January." - " "Domestic movements declined 4.4% to 187,778 in January." - " "For the third consecutive month, airports in Ontario reported the highest number of aircraft movements, with 86,959 in January." - " "Toronto/Lester B. Pearson International remained the busiest airport, with 31,499 movements, a 7.4% year-over-year increase." - " "The seven Canadian Level I air carriers flew 6.8 million passengers on scheduled and charter services in January, 10.9% more than in January 2023 when there were six Level I carriers." - " "Each passenger travelled an average of 2 750 kilometres in January, up 1.8% from January 2023." - " "Level I carriers flew 184,000 hours in January 2024 and generated $2.3 billion in total operating revenue."

Summary

In January 2024, Canada's major and select small airports saw a 5.9% decrease in aircraft movements, with local movements dropping 15.7% and itinerant movements down 2.1%. Major Canadian airlines flew 6.8 million passengers, a 10.9% increase from the previous year, though the passenger load factor slightly decreased to 83.1%. International traffic outside the US rose by 14.7%, while transborder movements with the US increased by 3.3%. Ontario airports had the highest aircraft movements, with Toronto's airport experiencing a 7.4% increase in activity.

Facts

    • -5.9% (317,569)
  • Local movements

quotes: "On Thursday, Ottawa announced that it will reduce the share of temporary residents to 5 per cent of the total population from 6.2 per cent over the next three years." - "The Canadian population grew by around 1.25 million or 3.2 per cent over the 12 months to Oct. 1, 2023." - "But Ottawa has conceded that recent growth is exacerbating some issues, such as access to housing and health care." - "And while Canada has struggled to build sufficient rental housing over decades, the recent rush of demand has pushed vacancy rates down to historic lows, according to Canada Mortgage and Housing Corp"
summary:
Summary

The Canadian government plans to reduce temporary residents from 6.2% to 5% of the population over three years, a 20% decrease from 2.5 million. This policy aims to ease housing demand and inflation, with population growth expected to slow to 1% from over 3%. The Bank of Canada notes immigration's long-term neutral inflation impact, but acknowledges short-term housing market imbalances. Shelter prices rose 6.5% in the past year, with rents increasing 8.2%. Additionally, the Temporary Foreign Worker Program's low-wage stream cap for certain sectors will drop from 30% to 20%.

Facts

Temporary residents' share - 1.2% decrease (from 6.2% to 5%) - 20% reduction (from current 2.5 million) Population growth rate - 2%+ decrease (from over 3% to closer to 1%) Shelter price inflation - 6.5% increase (over the past year) Rent inflation - 8.2% increase (over the past year) Headline inflation - 2.8% (as of February) Temporary Foreign Worker Program cap - 10% decrease (from 30% to 20% for certain sectors)
title: With move to limit temporary residents, Ottawa is ‘attacking the demand curve now’

Summary

Canadian male physicians, particularly married ones, have significantly reduced their working hours, contributing to 83% of the overall decline in physician work hours from 1987 to 2021. Despite more doctors per capita, Canada faces primary care access issues, with only 86% of adults having a regular care source in 2023, down from 93% in 2016. Average weekly hours for doctors dropped from 52.8 in 1987-1991 to 45.9 in 2017-2021, with male doctors reducing their hours by 5.7 hours of the 6.9-hour total decrease.

  • Primary care access (2023)
    • 86%
  • Hourly gap between male and female doctors (circa 1995)

title: Male doctors accounted for 83 per cent of reduction in physician work hours from 1987-2021, study says

quotes: "The staffing challenges in Ontario’s public education system have grown so dire that more than a quarter of schools experience daily teacher shortages and nearly half have daily shortages of education support workers, a new survey has found." - "School boards in many parts of the country have said they struggle to find substitute educators to help fill the voids left in classrooms when permanent staff are absent."
summary:
Summary

In Ontario, over a quarter of schools face daily teacher shortages, with 24% of elementary and 35% of high schools affected. Education support worker shortages are even higher, with 42% of elementary and 46% of secondary schools struggling daily. The survey by People for Education, based on responses from 1,030 principals, indicates that these shortages lead to safety concerns, with many students with special needs being asked to stay home. The Ontario government is seeking solutions, including increasing the number of days retired teachers can work without pension penalties.

Facts

  • Daily teacher shortages
    • 24% (elementary schools)
    • 35% (high schools)
  • Daily education support worker shortages
    • 42% (elementary schools)
    • 46% (secondary schools)
  • Survey response rate
    • Responses from 1,030 principals
  • Impact on students with special needs
    • More than half of secondary school principals
    • Nearly two-thirds of elementary principals
  • Retired teachers' workdays without pension penalty
    • Current: 50 days
    • Proposed: 95 days
title: Ontario’s public education system faces dire staffing challenges, survey finds

quotes: "The spike in freight crime comes in lockstep with a ramp-up of more sophisticated, digitally savvy tactics that revolve around identity theft and drain the economy of millions of dollars, as the higher cost of living drives demand for pilfered products." - "The number of cargo thefts – when goods are stolen during transportation – rose 59 per cent in Canada and the United States last year, according to data analytics firm Verisk’s CargoNet." - "Fictitious pickups – also called fraudulent pickups – jumped 600 per cent in 2022 in Canada and the U.S., though they still account for a minority of the total, according to CargoNet." - "The value of freight stolen across Canada and the U.S. last year totalled $449-million, a 47-per-cent jump from 2022, according to CargoNet."
summary:
```html

Summary

Peel police's Project Big Rig led to 15 arrests and the recovery of $7-million in stolen goods. Cargo thefts increased by 59% in Canada and the U.S. last year, with a 47% jump in the value of stolen freight to $449-million. Ontario accounts for 83% of Canada's cargo thefts, with theft methods evolving to include digital tactics and identity theft. High-value items like electronics, food, and beverages are targeted, and stolen goods often resurface in retail, posing health and economic risks.

quotes: "'triple-protected' jobs—defined as those that have no predetermined end date; have a low risk of being lost or transformed due to automation; and which are resilient to the effects of the COVID-19 pandemic—are less likely to be held by those with a bachelor's degree than by those with a graduate degree.'"

Summary

Early in the pandemic, 30.6% of graduates lost jobs, and 23.6% faced cancelled employment prospects. Employment rates for 2020 graduates were similar to 2015 graduates three years post-graduation, at 90.3%. However, those affected by the pandemic were less likely to be in full-time work (79.7%) and had a higher unemployment rate (7.5%) compared to unaffected graduates (3.6%). Pandemic-impacted graduates also earned less, with income reductions up to 16.3% for master's graduates. They were more likely to feel overqualified and less likely to have jobs related to their studies. Fewer pursued further education, with 34.3% changing their plans.

quotes: "'In February, 4.2 million passengers passed through pre-board security screening at checkpoints operated at Canada's eight largest airports, an increase of 11.2% from February 2023" - "Screened passenger traffic in February 2024 was just below (0.4% lower) the number posted in February 2020" - "In February 2024, there were 1.3 million passengers screened for international flights, up 18.9% over the same month in 2023" - "Nevertheless, international traffic volumes were 11.2% higher than the level reported in February 2020" - "Transborder traffic to the United States continued to be resilient on a year-over-year basis in February 2024, up 15.2%" - "Domestic screened traffic increased in February, posting a 3.1% gain over the same month in 2023" - "The 1.7 million domestic passenger screenings in February 2024 were 5.6% below the level in February 2020" - "At Montréal/Pierre Elliott Trudeau International, a run of 10 consecutive months starting in April 2023 that saw screened passengers exceed pre-pandemic levels was broken in February 2024, with screened traffic slightly below (-0.7%) that in February 2020'"

Summary

In February 2024, Canada's eight largest airports saw a 4.2 million passenger throughput, an 11.2% increase from February 2023 but 0.4% lower than February 2020. International passengers were up 18.9% from 2023 and 11.2% from February 2020. Transborder traffic to the US rose by 15.2%, yet remained 4.5% below pre-pandemic levels. Domestic traffic increased by 3.1% from 2023 but was 5.6% less than in 2020. Vancouver and Calgary airports exceeded their pre-pandemic passenger volumes, while Montréal broke a 10-month streak of surpassing pre-pandemic levels.

Facts

quotes: "Canada’s carbon pricing system for heavy industrial emitters is by far the country’s most impactful policy for reducing greenhouse gas emissions, and roughly three times more effective than the more controversial carbon price paid by most consumers, according to new research being released on Thursday." - ""It’s just a fact that industrial carbon pricing is the most important contributor to carbon reduction across the country." - Climate Institute president Rick Smith" - "Among the best ways to close that gap, it suggests, is by further strengthening the industrial carbon pricing system already doing the most heavy lifting."
summary:
```html

Summary

Canada's carbon pricing for heavy industrial emitters is deemed three times more effective than the consumer carbon price, according to the Canadian Climate Institute. Industrial pricing is projected to account for 20-48% of emission reductions from 2025 to 2030, while consumer pricing is expected to contribute 8-14%. To meet the 2030 goal of a 40% reduction from 2005 levels, Canada must address policy overlaps and increase stringency. Current policies are anticipated to prevent 226 megatonnes of annual emissions by 2030, but Canada may still fall 30-40 megatonnes short of its target.

Facts

  • Industrial carbon pricing effectiveness
    • 20-48% (between 2025 and 2030)
  • Consumer carbon pricing effectiveness
    • 8-14% (between 2025 and 2030)
  • Projected emissions reductions by 2030
    • 226 megatonnes (annually)
  • Gap to 2030 emissions target
    • 30-40 megatonnes (annually)

quotes: "“We still have one of the greatest talent concentrations in AI in the world. But we are in danger of losing it because now there’s so much money being invested in these large systems, mostly in the U.S., that the brain drain is probably coming back,” said Prof. Bengio, the scientific director at the Mila AI institute and professor at the Université de Montréal. " - "But when ranked on infrastructure, Canada fell from 15th to 23rd place compared with the previous study." - "Since March, 2023, Britain has announced about £1.7-billion ($2.9-billion) to expand compute access and build infrastructure. By comparison, Canada announced $40-million to boost AI compute in 2021." - "Canada trailed all of its G7 peers in terms of aggregate computing power, according to the report, and ranked second last when adjusted for gross domestic product." - "Others will scale down their research because of a lack of resources, partner with researchers in another country or try to get access through a commercial cloud provider such as Microsoft, Google or Amazon.com Inc." - "“Canadians are behind, and most of our demand came from the United States in our first full year,” - Dave King co-founder of Denvr Dataworks in Calgary" - "And for all of the hype and excitement, Canadian companies have been slow to adopt generative AI, which is still a nascent, unreliable and expensive technology that has to prove its worth." - "With generative AI specifically, the Conference Board of Canada estimated in February that the technology could add close to 2 per cent to Canada’s gross domestic product, assuming businesses adopt it."
summary:
Summary

Canada's AI computing infrastructure is lagging, with the Niagara system falling from 53rd to 212th in global rankings since 2018. The country's AI capacity is ranked fifth, but infrastructure fell from 15th to 23rd. The federal government's $125-million AI strategy in 2017 is insufficient for current demands, with calls for $1-billion to $10-billion in investment. The U.S. and other nations are heavily investing in computing power, while Canada's most powerful system, Narval, is now 134th globally. The Digital Research Alliance of Canada recommends doubling capacity, but funding and procurement are slow.

Facts

- Niagara's global computing system ranking - Dropped to 212th - Was 53rd at launch in 2018 - AI capacity global ranking for Canada - Ranked 5th - AI infrastructure global ranking for Canada - Fell to 23rd from 15th - Pan-Canadian Artificial Intelligence Strategy funding - Initial funding was $125 million in 2017 - Narval's global computing system ranking - Dropped to 134th - Was 83rd at launch in 2021 - Digital Research Alliance of Canada's recommendation - Capacity should be doubled - Federal government investment in AI compute - $40 million announced in 2021 - U.S. investment in computing power - Spending $52 billion on semiconductor manufacturing - Japan's investment in computing power - Allocated $13 billion for chips sector - Britain's investment in computing power - Announced about £1.7 billion ($2.9 billion) since March 2023 - Proposed Canadian investment in AI compute - Calls for at least $1 billion to start - Up to $10 billion over several years suggested
title: Canada’s AI infrastructure does not compute

quotes: "'94% of Canadians going online for personal use in 2022" - "82% of Internet users conducted online banking in 2022" - "the proportion of older adults using online banking increased from 62% in 2018 to 70% in 2022" - "16% of Canadians in the bottom family income decile did not have Internet access" - "less than 1% of those who were employed had no Internet access" - "76% of Internet users aged 65 to 74 banked online" - "90% of Internet users aged 25 to 34 managed a chequing or savings account online" - "70% of Internet users who were not employed banked online, while 89% of the employed used the Internet for this purpose" - "fewer than 8 in 10 Canadians in the lowest income deciles managed their personal and household finances online" - "88% of individuals who trusted banks and other financial institutions with their personal information banked online" - "79% of Internet users purchased goods and/or services online in 2022" - "almost 9 in 10 (89%) online shoppers using a credit card to pay for their purchases'"

Summary

Internet usage in Canada increased from 91% in 2018 to 94% in 2022, with online banking adoption growing especially among older adults (aged 65+), from 62% to 70%. Socio-economic factors significantly influence digital banking access; 16% of the lowest-income families lacked Internet access. Education and employment status also correlated with digital engagement. Trust in financial institutions and AI technology positively affected online banking usage. Online shopping was common among Internet users at 79%, with credit cards being the preferred payment method at 89%.

Facts

  • Internet usage in Canada
    • 3% increase (91% to 94%)
  • Online banking by older adults (65+)
    • 8% increase (62% to 70%)
  • Internet access by income

    • Employed banking online: 89%

  • Online banking by education

Summary

In January 2024, Canadian Employment Insurance beneficiaries remained stable, with a minor increase of 0.3% (1,600 individuals) from the previous month, totaling 468,000. Over the year, there was an 18.0% increase, partially recovering from the prior year's 40.6% decrease. Youth beneficiaries rose by 1.7%, with equal gains among young men and women.
