quotes: ""Growth had slowed in most regions." 'In the United States, economic activity also slowed but remained surprisingly strong." - "Growth in the euro area had been barely positive." - "In China, growth slowed as expected in the fourth quarter of 2023." - "Inflation had continued to ease in both the United States and the euro area." - "Equity markets were strong and credit spreads had narrowed since the January Report." - "Growth in gross domestic product (GDP) was somewhat higher than projected in the January Report, led by stronger exports." - "Labour markets continued to ease gradually, with employment growing more slowly than the population." - "Recent strength in resales could translate into a pickup in house prices and stoke shelter price inflation." - "The Bank’s preferred measures of core inflation were both lower, at 3.4% for CPI-trim and 3.3% for CPI-median, but still above 3%." - "Shelter price inflation, which includes mortgage interest costs, rent and components related to home ownership, remained high at 6.2% in January." - "If the housing sector rebounds in the spring, shelter price inflation could be pushed up, delaying the return of CPI inflation to the 2% target." - "If inflation proves more persistent than expected, monetary policy would likely need to remain restrictive for longer." - "Members agreed that the current stance of monetary policy was doing its work to slow economic growth and relieve price pressures, but that more time was needed to restore price stability." - "Governing Council therefore agreed to maintain the policy rate at 5%." - "Members agreed they need to see further and sustained easing in underlying inflation.'"
summary:

```html
Summary

The global economy has slowed, with the US showing surprising strength due to a robust labour market. Euro area growth is minimal, while China's investment activity, especially in property, has weakened. Inflation is easing in the US and euro area, with improved supply conditions and a downward trend in core inflation. Canadian GDP growth exceeded expectations in Q4 2023, driven by exports, but domestic demand fell. Canadian CPI inflation eased to 2.9% in January, with goods prices slowing but services remaining stable. Shelter costs continue to drive inflation, with high mortgage interest costs contributing significantly.

Facts

  • Global economic growth

  • Canadian domestic demand in Q4 2023
    • - Declined
  • Canadian employment growth
    • - Slower than population growth
  • Canadian wage growth
    • - Showing signs of easing
  • Canadian CPI inflation in January
    • - Eased to 2.9%
  • Canadian shelter price inflation in January
    • - High at 6.2%
  • Canadian core inflation measures
```

summary:

```html
Summary

In 2022, Canada's non-profit sector contributed $216.5 billion (8.2% of GDP). In 2023, 92.6% of non-profits had boards, with 47.3% positions held by women, and 9.8% by racialized groups. The general public was the primary service target (42.1%), with health and social services most reliant on provincial funding (43.6% and 42.5%, respectively). Individual donations were significant for registered charities (41.5%). Demand for non-profit services increased (46.1%), outpacing capacity growth (24.3%). The sector is volunteer-heavy (81.8%), with sports and recreation being the largest focus area (33.3%).
```

```html
Summary

In January 2024, urban transit trips in Canada increased by 11.9% year-over-year to 127.1 million, representing 79.0% of January 2019's pre-pandemic levels. This indicates a slight decline from December 2023's recovery rate of 79.9%. Ridership growth from December to January was 3.8%, impacted by labor disputes. Summary
```

```html
Self-reported data from 2018 indicates that 45% of Canadian teens aged 15 to 17 experienced dating violence, with emotional abuse at 45% being the most common. Physical violence was reported by 10%, and sexual violence by 7%. Police-reported data from 2009 to 2022 shows a 33% increase in dating violence since 2015, with 239 victims per 100,000 in this age group. Teen girls experience higher rates of police-reported dating violence, especially sexual violence, with 500 victims per 100,000 compared to 57 for boys.
```

quotes: "The resulting estimates raise concerns that B.C. taxpayers could be stuck with a hefty cleanup bill, said Simon Wiebe, mining policy and impacts researcher at Wildsight, which released the report on Tuesday"
summary:
```html

Summary

A new report suggests the cost to address selenium contamination from Teck Resources' Elk Valley coal mines could reach $6.4 billion, far above the $1.9 billion security bond held by the B.C. government. The estimate accounts for building and operating water treatment plants for 60 years. Wildsight, the report's publisher, fears taxpayers may bear the excess cost. Teck disputes the figures, claiming full compliance with provincial requirements. The issue has escalated to the International Joint Commission due to transboundary water concerns. Teck's recent sale of its coal operations adds to the uncertainty of addressing the pollution.

Facts

  • Estimated cost to tackle selenium contamination
    • $6.4-billion
  • Current security bond by the B.C. government
    • $1.9-billion
  • Percentage decrease in Teck Resources Ltd. stock
    • -1.51% decrease
  • Amount Teck has spent on water quality improvements
    • $1.4-billion
  • Additional investment by Teck by end of the year
    • $250-million
  • Percentage of mining liabilities covered by securities in B.C.
    • 90% (current)
    • 40% (before NDP took office)
```
title: Cleanup for pollution from Teck coal mines will top $6.4-billion, assessment claims

```html
Summary

Household credit growth is at its lowest since the 1980s, with real growth barely above zero and consumer credit in negative territory. Insolvencies have risen by over 20%, but are mostly debt restructuring proposals rather than bankruptcies. Delinquency rates are up, but early-stage delinquencies are declining. Half of all mortgages, over one trillion dollars' worth, are yet to reprice, with an estimated average interest payment shock of 15% per year from 2024 to 2026. Renters show signs of stress with rising delinquency rates, holding 60% of non-mortgage debt and 85% of serious delinquencies.
```

```html
Summary

Job vacancies in Canada decreased by 25,400 (-3.6%) to 678,500 in Q4 2023, continuing a downward trend from Q2 2022's high of 983,600. Payroll employment increased slightly by 37,700 (+0.2%). The job vacancy rate fell to 3.8%, the lowest since Q1 2021. Sales and service occupations saw the largest year-over-year decline in vacancies (-93,800; -31.5%). Health occupations vacancies decreased by 3,400 (-3.6%) year-over-year. The average offered hourly wage for vacant positions rose by 6.4% to $26.50. Job vacancies requiring a high school diploma or less experienced the largest decline (-31.1%; -154,600).
```

Summary

The CPI increased by 2.8% year-over-year in February, a slight decrease from January's 2.9%. Cellular services and Internet access saw significant price drops, while gasoline prices rose by 0.8% after a previous decline. Excluding gasoline, CPI growth slowed to 2.9%. Monthly, the CPI rose by 0.3%, with travel tours and gasoline as main contributors. Grocery price inflation eased with a 2.4% rise, notably slower than the previous month. Regionally, prices rose more slowly in seven provinces, with Alberta experiencing an increase due to higher natural gas prices.

quotes: "Canada remains concerned about any measures that may cause disruptions to the highly integrated North American meat and livestock supply chains."
summary:

```html
Summary

The U.S. Department of Agriculture's new voluntary labeling rules for "Product of USA" or "Made in the USA" are set to disrupt the integrated meat and livestock supply chains between Canada and the U.S. These labels will only apply to products from animals born, raised, slaughtered, and processed in the U.S. starting in 2026. Canadian officials express concern over potential trade disruptions and are reviewing the rule's compliance with international trade obligations. The Canadian meat industry, which has traded over $11.3 billion in exports to and imported nearly $4.9 billion from the U.S. since 2022, advocates for reduced trade barriers.

Facts

  • Labeling Rule Implementation Year
    • 2026
  • Canadian Exports to the U.S. (since 2022)
    • $11.3 billion
  • Canadian Imports from the U.S. (since 2022)
    • $4.9 billion
```
title: Product of U.S. meat label could disrupt cross-border trade

quotes: "The government of Newfoundland and Labrador spent $35.6-million on nurses from for-profit agencies in just five months last year, up from an average of about $1-million a year before the pandemic" - "he Globe reported last month that health authorities in one region of Newfoundland were paying a Toronto-based company, Canadian Health Labs, as much as $312 an hour for each nurse. "
summary:
```html

Summary

Mark Aylward, a nurse practitioner from Newfoundland and Labrador, participated in a pilot project aimed at reducing reliance on costly out-of-province travel nurses. The government spent $35.6 million on for-profit agency nurses in five months, a significant increase from the pre-pandemic $1 million annual average. The new program offers unionized nurses higher wages to work in rural areas, saving money compared to agency rates. Over 100 nurses have joined since September 2022, with the project extended to January 2025. Alberta has a similar program, paying an extra $25 per hour to fill staffing gaps.

Facts

  • Government spending on travel nurses
    • 3,460% ($34.6 million from $1 million)
  • Hourly rate for agency nurses (Canadian Health Labs)
    • $312
  • Hourly rate for unionized hospital registered nurses
    • $37.86 to $47.16
  • Hourly rate for nurses under the pilot project
    • $25 extra
  • Other staffing agency rates
    • $120 to $159.50
  • CHL's continued rate for supplying nurses
    • $172.22
  • Payment to nurses working for CHL
    • $85 to $100
  • Duration of the pilot project
    • Extended to January 2025
  • Number of nurses participating in the pilot project
    • Over 100
```
title: Newfoundland, eager to shed dependency on expensive travel nurses, launches program for rural communities

```html
B.C. Premier David Eby has expressed concern over potential national security risks posed by cargo cranes in Canadian ports, following a U.S. investigation into Shanghai Zhenhua Heavy Industries Co. Ltd. (ZPMC). The U.S. found hidden modems in cranes that could be exploited by China. ZPMC cranes, which constitute about 80% of those in American ports, are under scrutiny. Canadian agencies have been contacted for comment, but no official probe has been confirmed. ZPMC denies cybersecurity risks, while Canadian companies using ZPMC cranes assert their own security measures.
```

quotes: "Our results indicate that EVs couldpose a significant burden on Canadian electricity grids, with systemdemand (also known as load)increasing by as little as 7.5% to asmuch as 15.3%" - "We project that as manyas 13 new gas plants of 500-MW capacity might be required in Canada" - "Unless society begins almost immediately to develop the required generating infrastructure, it will not be possible to meet the expected demand that EVs might pose for electricity grids in Canada."
summary:
```html

Summary

Canadian EV sales grew from less than 1% in 2017 to 9.1% in Q4 2022, with higher rates in British Columbia (18%) and Quebec (14%). EV adoption could increase Canada's electricity load by 7.5% to 15.3%, requiring significant new generating capacity. Projections suggest the need for up to 13 new 500-MW gas plants or 10 new 1,000-MW hydroelectric facilities. Alternatively, nearly 5,000 wind turbines could be built, but would require backup from gas plants, hydropower, or batteries, potentially necessitating subsidies. Immediate development of infrastructure is crucial to meet EV demand.

Facts

  • EV market share
    • 2017: <1%
    • 2022 Q4: 9.1%
  • Regional EV market share (2022 Q4)
    • British Columbia: 18%
    • Quebec: 14%
  • Projected electricity load increase
    • Minimum: 7.5%
    • Maximum: 15.3%
  • Provincial load increase
    • Quebec: 4.6%
    • Ontario: 26.2%
  • Annual load increase (TWh)
    • Canada: 46.8 - 95.1 TWh
    • British Columbia: 4.4 - 9.3 TWh
    • Ontario: 19.0 - 38.2 TWh
    • Quebec: 10 - 21.7 TWh
  • New generating capacity requirements
    • Gas plants (500-MW): up to 13
    • Hydroelectric facilities (1,000-MW): up to 10
    • Wind turbines (3.5 MW): nearly 5,000
  • Backup capacity
    • Requirement: Subsidized backup from gas, hydro, or batteries
```
title: Ottawa’s EV mandate unrealistically requires the equivalent of 10 new mega hydro dams or 13 large natural gas plants nationwide within 11 years

quotes: ["'Thermal-electric power producers continued to be Canada's largest industrial user of water in 2021", 'Estimates produced by the Industrial Water Survey indicate that the three main groups of industries covered by the survey had a total water intake of 27.4 billion cubic metres in 2021, up 0.42% from 2020', 'The majority of water intake was returned to surface water after being used for industrial processes', 'Total water discharge for the three main groups of industries in 2021 was 25.7 billion cubic metres', 'Prior to discharge, these same industry groups recirculated 13.3 billion cubic metres of water in 2021, a decrease of 15.9% compared with 2020', 'From 2011 to 2021, in both the manufacturing and the thermal-electric power industry groups, there has been no notable change in intake, recirculation, or discharge volumes', "However there has been a gradual decrease in intake and discharge volumes in the mining industry group since 2017'"]

```html
Summary

Canada's industrial water intake was 27.4 billion cubic metres in 2021, a slight increase of 0.42% from 2020. Thermal-electric power producers were the largest users, accounting for 83.7% of intake and 84.7% of discharge. Manufacturing followed with 14.8% of intake and 13.2% of discharge, while mining contributed to 1.5% and 2.1% respectively. The majority of water, 83.7%, was sourced from self-supplied surface water. Water recirculation decreased by 15.9% to 13.3 billion cubic metres. No significant changes in intake, recirculation, or discharge volumes were observed in manufacturing and thermal-electric power industries over the past decade, but mining has seen a gradual decrease since 2017.
```

```html
In 2023, five years post-legalization, 38.4% of Canadians aged 18-24 and 34.5% aged 25-44 used cannabis, compared to 15.5% over 45. quotes: ["'Research to Insights: Tracking Canada's Evolving Supply Chain Links and their Effects", 'Manufacturing firms that participate in global value chains have, on average, 10% higher labour productivity and 6% higher wages than those that do not', "Canadian industries accounting for 25% of the country's economic output are exposed to potential external demand and supply shocks", 'Rising import prices accounted for about half of consumer inflation at its peak in the last three quarters of 2022', "From 2002 to 2022, Canada's imports shifted away from the United States, whose import share declined from 62% to 49%", "China's import share rose from 5% to 14% over the same period", 'The share of input requirements sourced from abroad rose from 19% in 2007 to 23% in 2019', "These smaller firms, which have less capacity to absorb import supply chain shocks, had on average fewer than two suppliers for each imported intermediate product'"]
```
summary:
```html

Summary

Canada's integration into global supply chains has led to 10% higher labour productivity and 6% higher wages in manufacturing firms involved in global value chains. However, 25% of Canada's economic output faces risks from external demand and supply shocks. Import prices contributed to half of the consumer inflation in the latter three quarters of 2022. Canada's imports from the US decreased from 62% to 49% between 2002 and 2022, while imports from China increased from 5% to 14%. Input requirements from abroad increased from 19% in 2007 to 23% in 2019.

Facts

  • Labor Productivity
    • +10% (higher in manufacturing firms in global value chains)
  • Wages
    • +6% (higher in manufacturing firms in global value chains)
  • Economic Output at Risk
    • 25% (exposed to external shocks)
  • Consumer Inflation from Imports
    • 50% (contribution to inflation in last three quarters of 2022)
  • Imports from the United States
    • -13% (from 62% to 49% between 2002 and 2022)
  • Imports from China
    • +9% (from 5% to 14% between 2002 and 2022)
  • Input Requirements Sourced from Abroad
    • +4% (from 19% in 2007 to 23% in 2019)
```
title: Tracking Canada's evolving supply chain links and their effects: Knowns and unknowns

quotes: ["'The total amount donated fell for the first time since 2016, decreasing 3.1% to $11.4 billion.", 'The number of tax filers reporting donations of $100,000 or more fell by 12.4% in 2022, after rising by one-third (+33.6%) in 2021.', 'Tax filers with incomes of $100,000 or more continued to account for the largest share of charitable giving in 2022 (+0.9 percentage points to 59.1%).', 'Seniors had the highest median donation ($590).', 'Men continue to donate more overall, accounting for 63.4% of total charitable donations.', 'The overall decline in charitable donations in 2022 was driven by British Columbia (-11.8%) and Ontario (-6.0%).', "Manitoba remained Canada's most charitable province in 2022 with just under one in five tax filers (19.3%) declaring a donation on their tax form.", "Steinbach (-1.7% to $2,230) and Winkler (+0.0% to $1,820) remained Canada's most charitable urban centres of 10,000 or more people in 2022.'"]

```html
Summary

In 2022, 17.1% of Canadian tax filers reported charitable donations, a slight decrease from the previous year, with total donations falling by 3.1% to $11.4 billion. Median donations increased by 5.6% to $380. Donations of $100,000 or more saw a 12.4% decline in the number of donors and a 13.4% decrease in total amount donated. Higher-income filers contributed 59.1% of total donations, with those earning $1 million or more reporting the highest median donation at $5,150. Seniors were the most charitable, with those aged 65 or older contributing $48 for every $100 donated. Men were more likely to donate than women, contributing 63.4% of total donations. British Columbia and Ontario led the decrease in donations, while Manitoba remained the most charitable province.

Facts
```

```html
Summary

In 2021, 64.7% of eligible children aged 5 to 17 outside Quebec participated in regular French programs. This varied by region, age, education level, and eligibility under section 23 of the Charter. At least one municipality per province and the Northwest Territories had over 80% of eligible children attending French-language schools. However, only 35.5% of eligible youth aged 12 to 17 attended French-language secondary schools. Additionally, 60.4% of children with a French-speaking parent attended French-language schools, versus 40.9% with parents who did not have French as a mother tongue but attended French-language schools themselves.
```

quotes: ["'Households were wealthier in the fourth quarter as their net worth—the value of all assets minus all liabilities—increased $289.8 billion (+1.8%) to $16,419.9 billion", 'This increase was driven by strength in financial markets as both bonds and equities rallied after losing ground in the prior quarter', 'This pushed financial assets higher by nearly half a trillion dollars to a new record high of $9,741.3 billion, surpassing the previous record set in the fourth quarter of 2021', 'the slowest accumulation of household debt in a calendar year since 1990', 'The household saving rate (seasonally adjusted) stood at 6.2% in the fourth quarter', 'Households recorded $11.8 billion in net acquisitions of mutual fund shares in the fourth quarter of 2023', 'The value of household residential real estate decreased 1.9% in the fourth quarter, the second consecutive decline', 'During the fourth quarter, the pace of household credit market borrowing (seasonally adjusted) continued to rise, reaching $29.5 billion', 'The household debt service ratio, measured as total obligated payments of principal and interest on credit market debt as a proportion of household disposable income, rose slightly to 15.00% in the fourth quarter from 14.99% in the third quarter', 'In the fourth quarter, the federal government borrowed $22.0 billion in bonds and treasury bills', 'The demand for funds by private non-financial corporations fell to $8.9 billion in the fourth quarter from $21.7 billion in the third quarter', "National net worth, the sum of national wealth and Canada's net foreign asset position, rose $251.0 billion in the fourth quarter despite a decline in national wealth", "Specifically, Canada's international financial assets were up by $613.1 billion (+7.3%) to $9,037.6 billion at the end of the fourth quarter, the highest quarterly increase on record'"]
summary:
```html

Summary

Household net worth in Canada increased by $289.8 billion (+1.8%) to $16,419.9 billion in Q4, driven by a financial market rally. Financial assets hit a record $9,741.3 billion, while residential real estate values fell by $157.8 billion. The household saving rate was stable at 6.2%. Consumer credit spiked, with a $29.5 billion increase in household borrowing. The household debt service ratio slightly rose to 15.00%. Summary
```

```html
Hate crimes in Canada increased by 7% in 2022, with a cumulative rise of 83% since 2019. The majority of the increase was due to crimes targeting race or ethnicity (+12%) and sexual orientation (+12%). Violent hate crimes rose by 12%, while non-violent crimes increased by 3%. Hate crimes against religion decreased by 15%, yet remained above the numbers from 2018 to 2020. Ontario, Nova Scotia, and British Columbia had the highest rates of hate crime. Victims were predominantly men and boys, except in crimes targeting sex or gender. Less than one-third of hate crimes were cleared in 2022.
```

summary:
Summary

Canada's net foreign asset position reached a new high of $1,677.3 billion at the end of 2023, with a $288.2 billion increase in the fourth quarter alone. This growth was driven by global equity market strength, with a $317.1 billion increase due to market prices. The Canadian dollar's fluctuations against other major currencies had a moderating effect. International financial assets rose by $613.1 billion to $9,037.6 billion, while international liabilities increased by $324.9 billion to $7,360.3 billion. Canada's gross external debt also grew, reaching $4,150.3 billion, or 140.6% of GDP. Throughout 2023, the net foreign asset position grew by $584.2 billion.

```html
In 2021, Canada's full-time equivalent (FTE) R&D personnel increased by 5.8% to 298,850 FTEs, marking the fifth consecutive year of growth. Summary
```

```html
Canadian farmers are projected to plant more wheat, corn for grain, oats, lentils, and dry peas in 2024, while seeding less canola, soybeans, and barley. Wheat acreage is expected to edge up slightly by 0.1% to 27.0 million acres, with an increase in durum wheat but decreases in spring and winter wheat. Canola is set to decrease by 3.1% to 21.4 million acres. Soybean acreage will drop by 0.9% to 5.6 million acres. Barley will decline by 2.5% to 7.1 million acres, while oats will surge by 21.6% to 3.1 million acres. Corn for grain is expected to rise by 1.6% to 3.9 million acres. Lentils will increase by 4.4% to 3.8 million acres, and dry peas will go up by 2.4% to 3.1 million acres.
```

```html
Summary

In February 2024, international arrivals to Canada increased by 18.6% from the previous year. Non-resident air arrivals rose by 23.0%, surpassing pre-pandemic levels for the first time since COVID-19 began. Canadian residents returning from abroad by air increased by 15.8%, while US residents traveling to Canada by automobile went up by 18.8%. Canadian-resident return trips by automobile also saw a 20.7% rise. The busiest days coincided with US Presidents' Day and Canadian Family Day holidays.
```

quotes: ['"The family institution has undergone important transformations in recent decades" - "landed immigrant women were less likely than Canadian-born women to experience the dissolution of their first union" - "the effect of other sociodemographic characteristics, such as age at the start of the union and the highest level of education attained, varies by sex and landed immigrant status"']
summary:
```html

Summary

A study based on the 2017 General Social Survey – Family reveals that landed immigrant women in Canada have a lower risk of first union dissolution compared to Canadian-born women. The analysis considers sociodemographic factors affecting union stability, including type of union, presence of children, age at union start, and education level. While some factors like union type and children have a consistent impact across groups, others such as age and education level show varying effects based on sex and immigration status.

Facts

  • Landed Immigrant Status
    • Lower risk of first union dissolution for immigrant women compared to Canadian-born
  • Type of Union
    • Consistent impact on first union dissolution risk across groups
  • Presence of Children
    • Consistent impact on first union dissolution risk across groups
  • Age at Start of Union
    • Varying impact on first union dissolution risk based on sex and immigration status
  • Highest Level of Education Attained
    • Varying impact on first union dissolution risk based on sex and immigration status
```
title: Study: The duration of first unions: A comparative analysis between landed immigrants and Canadian-born individuals

```html
Summary

Employment in Canada increased by 41,000 (+0.2%) in February, with gains in full-time work (+71,000; +0.4%) and among core-aged women (+45,000; +0.7%) and men (+23,000; +0.3%). However, population growth outpaced employment growth, leading to a 0.1 percentage point drop in the employment rate to 61.5%. The unemployment rate rose slightly to 5.8%. Service industries saw employment growth, particularly in accommodation and food services (+26,000; +2.4%) and professional, scientific, and technical services (+18,000; +0.9%). Average hourly wages increased by 5.0% year-over-year to $34.82.
```

```html
Canadian industries' capacity utilization slightly decreased to 78.7% in Q4 from 78.8% in Q3. In 2023, women constituted 30.6% of MPs in the House of Commons, a rise from 20.6% in 1997. Cabinet achieved gender parity with women representing 48.7%, a significant increase from 24.3% in 2002. Summary
```

```html
January 2024 saw a decline in monthly prices for wheat (excluding durum) in the Prairie provinces, with Manitoba experiencing the largest year-over-year drop at -24.1%. Canola prices also fell across all provinces, with Quebec leading the decline at -11.2%. Conversely, dry peas prices increased in the Prairie provinces, with Saskatchewan seeing the highest rise at +6.6%. Slaughter cattle prices varied, with year-over-year gains in each province of at least +16.3%. Feeder cattle prices increased in Western provinces, with Alberta up by +3.3%, and saw year-over-year gains across all provinces, with Alberta having the highest at +39.1%. Hog prices had mixed movements, with Ontario leading monthly gains at +2.8%.

Facts
```

quotes: ["'Federal and provincial governments earned $15.5 billion (+2.5%) from the control and sale of alcohol and recreational cannabis", 'The increase in alcohol sales was driven by increased prices', 'By volume, beer sales declined to 65.1 litres of beer per year per person of legal drinking age in 2022/2023, an all-time low', 'The inflation rate of 7.4% for wine purchased from stores from March 2022 to March 2023 was responsible for the increase in sales', 'Ciders and coolers was the lone beverage category with an increase in sales by volume', 'Total spirit sales rose 3.0% to $6.9 billion in 2022/2023', 'Sales of recreational cannabis by provincial cannabis authorities and other retail outlets increased 15.8%, or by $0.6 billion, to $4.7 billion in 2022/2023', "The reversal of Newfoundland and Labrador's ban on cannabis vapes in 2022 is a major reason for the growth in sales of inhaled extracts in the province", "The market share of inhaled extracts increased from 18.1% to 24.9% in 2022/2023'"]

```html
Summary

Federal and provincial governments collected $15.5 billion from alcohol and cannabis sales, marking a 2.5% increase from the previous fiscal year. Alcohol sales rose by 2.8% to $26.3 billion, driven by a 5.9% price increase, despite a 1.1% drop in volume. Beer per capita sales hit a record low, while wine volume sales fell by 3.0%. Ciders and coolers saw a modest volume increase of 0.6%. Spirit sales grew by 3.0%, but volume slightly decreased. Recreational cannabis sales surged by 15.8% to $4.7 billion, with inhaled extracts contributing significantly to this growth.

Facts
```

```html
Summary

Canadian businesses experienced a 0.4% rise in labour productivity in Q4, marking the first increase since Q1 of 2022. Hours worked remained stable, with slight changes in employment and average hours worked. Productivity improved in both goods-producing (+0.1%) and service-producing (+0.4%) sectors. Unit labour costs decreased by 0.1%, the first drop after 12 quarters of increases. Annually, labour productivity fell by 1.8% in 2023, with goods-producing sectors down 3.4% and service sectors down 0.8%, reflecting a 0.6% rise in real GDP and a 2.5% increase in hours worked.
```

quotes: ['"Use of Government COVID-19 Liquidity Support Programs by Immigrant-owned Businesses and Those Owned by Canadian-born Individuals"']
summary:
```html

Summary

Immigrant-owned businesses in Canada were more affected by the COVID-19 pandemic, leading to higher usage of government support programs compared to those owned by Canadian-born individuals. They received 33% of CEBA loans, 37% of CECE aid, but only 14% of CEWS subsidies. When adjusting for business characteristics, immigrant-majority-owned businesses were more likely to receive CEBA and CECE support but less likely to benefit from CEWS. The total support value for these businesses was 6% higher on average than for Canadian-born owned businesses.

Facts

  • Ownership by immigrants
    • 25% (One in four businesses)
  • CEBA loans
    • 33% (One-third of total loan)
  • CECE aid
    • 37%
  • CEWS subsidies
    • 14% (Over one-tenth)
  • Total support value
    • 6% higher for immigrant-majority-owned businesses
```

quotes: ["'Operating revenues rose 15.4% from one year earlier to a record-high $13.3 billion", 'the fastest paces being in the Northwest Territories (+21.7%), Ontario (+18.4%), Alberta (+14.5%) and Nova Scotia (+13.8%)', "the industry's operating profit margin eased to 15.3% in 2022", 'Salaries, wages, commissions and benefits continued to account for the largest share of industry expenditures in 2022, reaching $5.0 billion', 'Subcontracts accounted for an increased share of industry expenditures, rising from 7.2% in 2021 to 7.6% in 2022', 'display advertising rose in 2021 and 2022', 'Programmatic advertising services, which facilitate the automated sale and purchase of online advertising, expanded in 2022', 'the share of sales to businesses outside Canada grew 1.4 percentage points to 15.1%', 'the advertising and related services industry is expected to continue to grow in 2023', "more modest growth is anticipated for operating revenue'"]

Summary

The Canadian advertising and related services industry saw a 15.4% increase in operating revenues in 2022, reaching $13.3 billion. Growth was observed across most regions, with the Northwest Territories, Ontario, Alberta, and Nova Scotia leading. Operating profit margins decreased slightly to 15.3%. Operating expenses rose by 18.6%, with salaries and wages comprising 44.4% of these expenses. Subcontracting expenses also grew. Sales to businesses outside Canada increased by 1.4 percentage points to 15.1%. The industry is expected to continue growing in 2023, albeit at a slower rate due to economic factors.

quotes: ["'In January, 4.3 million passengers passed through pre-board security screening at checkpoints operated at Canada's eight largest airports, an increase of 10.2% from January 2023", 'This was the second straight month in which traffic was below pre-pandemic levels, after having surpassed them for five consecutive months from July to November 2023', 'In January 2024, other international traffic (outside the United States) was up 17.0% year over year', 'The number of passengers screened for these international flights, at 1.4 million, was 4.7% higher than the level reported in January 2020, marking the fourth consecutive month in which international traffic exceeded pre-pandemic levels', 'Transborder traffic to the United States was also strong on a year-over-year basis in January 2024, up 14.1%', 'Domestic screenings in January 2024 were 6.1% below the January 2020 level, as passenger volumes failed to exceed pre-pandemic levels for a third straight month', "Canada's eight largest airports all experienced higher volumes of screened passenger traffic from the same month in 2023, with six of the eight airports up by more than 9.0% year over year", "In January 2024, three of Canada's eight largest airports surpassed their pre-pandemic screened passenger volumes from January 2020: Calgary International (+4.0%), Montréal-Trudeau International (+2.8%) and Halifax Stanfield International (+2.1%)", "Notably, this marked the 10th consecutive month in which volumes at Montréal-Trudeau exceeded pre-pandemic levels'"]
summary:
Summary

In January 2024, 4.3 million passengers were screened at Canada's eight largest airports, up 10.2% from January 2023 but 2.6% below January 2020. International traffic outside the US rose by 17.0% year-over-year, with 1.4 million passengers, 4.7% above January 2020. Transborder traffic to the US increased by 14.1%, yet remained below pre-pandemic levels. Domestic traffic was up 2.8% from 2023 but 6.1% below January 2020. Six airports saw over 9.0% growth, with Calgary, Montréal-Trudeau, and Halifax exceeding January 2020 volumes.

quotes: ["'Exports of goods and services rose 1.4% in the fourth quarter", 'Household spending increased 0.2% in the fourth quarter', 'Housing investment was down 0.4% in the fourth quarter', 'Real business investment declined for the sixth time over the last seven quarters', 'Businesses continued to add to their inventories in the fourth quarter (+$30.4 billion)', 'The ratio of the price of exports to the price of imports—the terms of trade—fell 0.5% in the fourth quarter', 'Compensation of employees rose 0.8% in the fourth quarter of 2023, the slowest growth rate since the second quarter of 2020', 'The household saving rate was little changed in the fourth quarter, at 6.2%', "Corporate incomes increased 2.9%, after rising 3.4% in the third quarter'"]
summary: In Q4 2023, Canada's real GDP grew by 0.2%, driven by increased exports (up 1.4%) and decreased imports (down 0.4%), despite a 0.2% decline in final domestic demand. Exports were boosted by crude oil and travel services, while imports fell due to lower demand for intermediate metal products and vehicles. Household spending rose slightly by 0.2%, with growth in vehicle purchases but a decline in spending abroad. Housing investment dropped by 0.4%, with a slowdown in the resale market. Business investment also declined, with a 3.0% decrease in non-residential structures. Inventory investment slowed, with a $30.4 billion increase. The terms of trade fell by 0.5% in Q4 and 5.9% over the year. Employee compensation grew by 0.8%, the slowest since Q2 2020. The household saving rate remained stable at 6.2%, and corporate incomes rose by 2.9%, with non-financial corporations growing by 3.3% and financial corporations declining by 1.8%.
title: Gross domestic product, income and expenditure, fourth quarter 2023

quotes: ["'impacted heavily by the public sector workers' strike in Quebec", 'The strike had the greatest impact on the elementary and secondary schools industry', 'The electric power generation, transmission, and distribution industry contributed the most to the decrease', 'The transportation equipment manufacturing subsector was the largest contributor to the decline in December', 'crude oil production reached a new record high level in December', 'Market sentiment rose and buying activity on the Toronto Stock Exchange increased following the US Federal Reserve interest rate announcement', 'The public sector was the largest detractor to growth in the fourth quarter', 'Real GDP by industry increased 1.2% in 2023, its slowest growth rate since 2016 aside from the contraction recorded in 2020', 'The public sector grew 2.5% in 2023 and contributed the most to the increase in services-producing industries', "The construction sector was the largest detractor to growth, contracting for the first time since 2020'"]
summary: In December, Canada's real GDP remained flat, with a 0.2% contraction in goods-producing industries and unchanged services-producing industries. A public sector strike in Quebec led to a 1.0% decline in public sector output, with educational services dropping 3.8%. Utilities shrank by 3.6%, influenced by warmer weather and drought conditions. Construction fell 0.6%, and manufacturing declined 0.4%, with transportation equipment manufacturing down 3.1%. Mining, quarrying, and oil and gas extraction grew by 1.5%, driven by record crude oil production. The finance and insurance sector expanded by 0.8%, retail trade grew for the fourth month by 0.7%, and wholesale trade increased by 0.5%. An early estimate suggests a 0.4% GDP increase in January 2024. The fourth quarter of 2023 saw a 0.2% GDP rise, with mining and retail trade contributing positively, while public sector and construction declined. Overall, 2023 GDP growth slowed to 1.2%, with the public sector and client-facing industries as main growth drivers, while goods-producing industries, especially construction, tempered growth.
title: Gross domestic product by industry, December 2023

quotes: ["'Farm cash receipts totalled $98.6 billion in 2023, up 3.6% (+$3.4 billion) compared with 2022", 'Livestock receipts rose 9.8% to $37.3 billion in 2023 because of increases in the cattle and supply managed sectors', 'Total crop receipts in 2023 were up 2.0% to $54.9 billion, compared with 2022', "Total direct payments dropped by $983.0 million (-13.4%) to $6.4 billion in 2023, compared with 2022'"]
summary: In 2023, Canadian farm cash receipts increased by 3.6% to $98.6 billion, with livestock receipts up 9.8% to $37.3 billion, largely due to a $2.7 billion rise in cattle receipts. Crop receipts grew 2.0% to $54.9 billion, with significant gains in wheat and potatoes, but declines in corn and soybeans. Supply managed receipts, including dairy and chicken, also rose. All provinces except Ontario saw increases. Direct payments to farmers decreased by 13.4% to $6.4 billion, with a notable drop in crop insurance payments from the previous year's high, but still above the five-year average.
title: Farm cash receipts, January to December 2023

quotes: ["'In December, Canada's major and select small airports recorded a total of 352,280 aircraft movements, up 13.1% from December 2022", 'The number of international movements between Canada and countries other than the United States was up 18.1% year over year to 18,422 movements in December 2023', 'Toronto/Lester B. Pearson International remained the busiest airport and recorded the largest year-over-year increase in December (+3,475 movements; +11.8%)', "Natural Resources Canada reported 2023 to be the worst wildfire season in Canada's recorded history", "There were 5.5 million aircraft movements in 2023, up from 5.2 million (+5.5%) in 2022 and reaching 89.6% of the 2019 level'"]
summary: In 2023, Canada's major and select small airports saw a 13.1% increase in aircraft movements from December 2022, totaling 352,280. Itinerant movements rose by 8.8% to 260,236, while local movements surged by 27.7% to 92,044. The year ended with 5.5 million movements, 5.5% higher than in 2022 and 90% of 2019's volume. International movements excluding the US grew by 18.1%, while US-related traffic increased by 9.7%. Domestic movements within Canada went up by 7.9%. Most provinces saw traffic increases, with Ontario leading. Wildfires in 2023 led to heightened activity from smaller carriers. Despite recovery, many airports still lagged behind pre-pandemic levels.
title: Aircraft movement statistics: Major and select small airports, December 2023

file_2: Employment, Future Workforce Development and Disability Inclusion
quotes: ['"Wage growth lagged, cutting into household purchasing power." \' "Real" (after adjusted for inflation) wages declined by about 1% in 2021 and 2.5% in 2022 before picking up in 2023.', 'Over the last 30 years, real worker pay per hour has moved largely in lockstep with productivity growth.', 'Productivity underperformance versus the U.S. has increased relative unit labour costs in Canada by about 5%.', "Sustained growth in worker pay significantly above the rate of inflation over the longer run—which is critical to ensuring living standards continue to improve—will also depend on ensuring that the weak productivity performance does not persist.'"]
summary: Canadian wage growth has been high but not sufficient to keep pace with inflation, especially considering the tight labor market earlier in the pandemic recovery. Real wages fell by 1% in 2021 and 2.5% in 2022, with only a slight recovery in 2023. Canada's productivity growth is lagging, ranking 5th among G7 countries since 2019, with output per hour worked falling below 2019 levels. This underperformance is increasing unit labor costs and reducing competitiveness relative to the U.S. The labor market is softening, with unemployment rising and job openings decreasing, which may slow wage growth further. Long-term wage increases depend on productivity growth, which is hindered by low business investment and ineffective utilization of immigrant skills. Without improvements in productivity, living standards may stagnate.
title: Weak productivity is threatening Canada’s post-pandemic wage growth

quotes: ["'Canada's current account balance recorded a $1.6 billion deficit in the fourth quarter, narrowing $3.1 billion from the previous quarter.", 'The trade in goods and services balance posted a $1.2 billion surplus in the fourth quarter.', 'Canadian investors acquired $33.5 billion of foreign securities in the fourth quarter.', "For the year 2023, the current account balance posted a $17.8 billion deficit, up $7.4 billion compared with 2022.'"]
summary: Canada's current account deficit decreased to $1.6 billion in Q4, with a stronger goods surplus. Exports rose by $2.9 billion, led by energy products, while imports increased marginally. The services deficit narrowed, and the financial account saw Canadian investors acquire $33.5 billion in foreign securities. For 2023, the current account deficit grew to $17.8 billion, with a significant drop in energy exports. Services exports increased, driven by travel and commercial services. Direct and portfolio investments resulted in a net outflow, with Canadians investing heavily in foreign securities, particularly in US bonds and shares. Foreign investment in Canadian securities continued, albeit at a reduced pace.
title: Canada's balance of international payments, fourth quarter 2023

quotes: ["'Canadian men inventors outnumbered women inventors, but the number of women inventors grew at a faster pace", 'Women inventors were more likely to be younger and a higher proportion of them were immigrants', 'One-half of women inventors were repeat inventors, submitting more than one patent application over time', 'Lower Grade 10 marks in English, science and math accounted for a large share of the gaps in educational outcomes', 'The citizenship rate—the proportion of immigrants who acquire Canadian citizenship after they meet the residency requirement—has decreased from 75% in 1996 to 46% in 2021', 'Almost half of this decline in citizenship rates occurred from 2016 to 2021', 'This decline in citizenship rates was larger among recent immigrants with lower levels of education, lower family income and lower language skills', 'There was a notable increase of 8 percentage points in the employment rate among recent immigrants, compared with a 3 percentage point rise among Canadian-born workers', "The gap in weekly earnings between recent immigrants and Canadian-born workers has narrowed'"]
summary: Women inventors in Canada are increasing at a faster rate than men, with a higher proportion being younger, immigrants, and working in large businesses. Black and Latin American youth in British Columbia have lower high school graduation and postsecondary enrollment rates than White youth, largely due to lower academic performance in key subjects. Canadian citizenship acquisition among recent immigrants has declined from 75% in 1996 to 46% in 2021, with the pandemic contributing to recent drops. Recent immigrants have seen faster employment rate growth and narrowing earnings gaps compared to Canadian-born workers, likely due to changes in immigration selection and economic conditions.
title: Economic and Social Reports, February 2024

quotes: ["'Net saving deteriorates for lower- and middle-income households as renters and lower-income families are spending more than they make", 'Prospective young homeowners turn away from the housing market, while homeowners pay off debt or look for affordable housing', "Real estate continues to be central to wealth accumulation across the life cycle'"]
summary: Canadian households face increasing financial pressures with the highest debt to disposable income ratios in the G7. The "Research to Insights" presentation reveals that post-pandemic net financial gains are concentrated among the wealthiest, while lower- and middle-income families see a decline in net saving. Younger households are increasingly burdened by debt service costs and are retreating from the housing market, threatening socioeconomic mobility as homeownership becomes less attainable. Real estate remains central to wealth accumulation, with 55% of an average household's wealth tied to property, but the distribution of wealth is skewed towards older Canadians, posing risks for future intergenerational mobility.
title: Disparities in wealth and debt among Canadian households

quotes: ["'Major Canadian airlines carried 6.8 million passengers on scheduled and charter services in December, up 10.7% from the same month in 2022", 'Canadian Level I air carriers flew 6.8 million passengers on scheduled and charter services in December 2023, which was 5.8% below the pre-pandemic level reported in December 2019', 'Operating revenue earned by Canadian Level I air carriers totalled $2.5 billion in December, 14.3% higher than in December 2019', 'Canadian Level I air carriers flew 79.6 million passengers, a 27.0% increase over 2022 and 6.8% below the 2019 level', 'The overall load factor for 2023 was 86.0%, higher than the 84.3% recorded in 2019', "In 2023, operating revenue exceeded pre-pandemic levels in every month and totalled $28.3 billion, 11.8% higher than in 2019'"]
summary: In December 2023, Canadian airlines carried 6.8 million passengers, a 10.7% increase from 2022 but 5.8% below December 2019 levels. The passenger load factor was 82.8%, with 18.1 billion passenger-kilometres flown. Throughout 2023, 79.6 million passengers were transported, marking a 27% increase from 2022, yet 6.8% less than in 2019. The year saw a gradual recovery from the pandemic, with passenger numbers and load factors nearing pre-pandemic levels, particularly in October and November. Operating revenue for December reached $2.5 billion, 14.3% higher than in 2019, with the annual total at $28.3 billion, up 11.8% from 2019.
title: Monthly civil aviation statistics, December 2023

quotes: ["'Children and adults whose mother tongue is not French and who were in or had been in French immersion for at least one year were 12 times more likely to be able to have a conversation in French (50.2%) than those who had never been in immersion (4.1%)'"]
summary: The "Participation in French immersion, bilingualism and the use of French in adulthood, 2021" report reveals that in Canada outside Quebec, 16.9% of children aged 5 to 17 with a non-French mother tongue were in French immersion. These individuals were 12 times more likely to converse in French (50.2%) compared to those not in immersion (4.1%). The study, based on 2021 Census data, examines factors influencing French immersion program participation and its impact on bilingualism and French usage in personal and professional settings.
title: 2021 Census of Population: Analytical product on participation in French immersion

quotes: ["'payroll employment was up by 223,500 (+1.3%) in December 2023", 'Payroll employment in elementary and secondary schools increased by 56,800 (+7.2%)', 'Job vacancies were down by 209,200 (-24.7%) compared with December 2022', 'Payroll employment in health care and social assistance increased by 8,300 (+0.4%) in December', 'Payroll employment in public administration was up by 4,700 (+0.4%) in December', 'Payroll employment in construction rose by 2,700 (+0.2%)', 'payroll employment in retail trade (-26,700; -1.3%) decreased', 'average weekly earnings were down 1.1% to $1,212 in December', 'Overall job vacancies held steady at 637,400 in December', 'Retail trade (-9,400; -13.8%) was the only sector to record a decline in job vacancies in December', 'job vacancies declined by 9,400 (-13.8%) to 58,800 in retail trade', 'Job vacancies in health care and social assistance were little changed in December 2023 (125,900)', "In Ontario, the number of vacant positions decreased by 13,400 (-5.6%) to 224,200 in December'"]
summary: In December 2023, Canadian payroll employment rose by 31,600 (+0.2%), totaling a year-over-year increase of 223,500 (+1.3%). The education sector saw a significant rebound with 56,800 new jobs (+7.2%) after a temporary dip due to the Quebec public sector strike. Excluding education, payroll employment fell by 25,200 (-0.1%). Job vacancies remained stable at 637,400, a significant drop from the previous year (-24.7%) and from the May 2022 peak (-36.5%). Health care and social assistance, public administration, and construction sectors experienced employment growth, while retail trade saw a decline. Average weekly earnings decreased by 1.1% to $1,212 in December, but year-over-year earnings grew by 3.8%. Job vacancies decreased in retail trade but increased in education and utilities, with retail trade vacancies at their lowest since November 2019. Job vacancies also fell in Ontario and Quebec, while they rose in Nova Scotia and Prince Edward Island.
title: Payroll employment, earnings and hours, and job vacancies, December 2023

quotes: ["'The total fertility rate (TFR) observed in Canada in 2022 (1.33 children per woman) is the lowest recorded over more than a century of data", 'The decline in the TFR observed in Canada from 2021 to 2022 (-7.4%) was the largest since 1971-1972 (-7.6%)', 'The sharp drop in fertility from 2021 to 2022 was observed in most (11 out of 13) provinces and territories', 'Among women aged 20 to 39, this is the biggest decrease since 1978-1979', "In 2022, Canada's TFR (1.33 children per woman) ranked in the middle of the pack of 10 selected high-income countries", "The 7.4% decline in fertility observed in Canada from 2021 to 2022 ranked third among these same countries, after the Netherlands (-8.4%) and Germany (-7.7%)'"]
summary: In 2022, Canada's total fertility rate (TFR) fell to a historic low of 1.33 children per woman, marking the largest decline (-7.4%) since 1971-1972. This drop, which accelerated during the COVID-19 pandemic, was observed in most provinces and territories, particularly among women aged 20 to 39. Canada's TFR now ranks in the middle among selected high-income countries, with South Korea at the lowest (0.78) and France at the highest (1.80). The decline in Canada's fertility rate is the third steepest after the Netherlands and Germany, indicating a potential pandemic-related disruption in fertility behaviors.
title: Canada's fertility rate reaches an all-time low in 2022

quotes: ['"The 2022 rate of firearm-related violent crime is the highest since comparable data were first compiled in 2009." \' "The increase in firearm-related violent crime in Ontario was largely driven by an increase in the number of these crimes in Toronto." \' "The rate of firearm-related violent crime has generally been increasing since 2013, with the increase higher in rural areas." \' "The rate of firearm-related violent crime in 2022 was higher for most violent offences." \' "The rate of firearm-related homicide in 2022 (0.88 homicides per 100,000 population) was the highest rate since 1991." \' "Since 2013, the rate of firearm-related violent crime has risen for all types of weapons."']
summary: In 2022, Canada saw a 36.7 per 100,000 population rate of firearm-related violent crimes, an 8.9% increase from 2021, marking the highest rate since 2009. Ontario, particularly Toronto, drove this rise, with a 24% increase in Ontario alone. British Columbia and Alberta also saw significant increases, with urban centers contributing most to the rise. Since 2013, firearm-related violent crime has risen by 55%, with rural and northern regions showing the largest increases. Discharging a firearm with intent saw a 244% increase since 2013. Handgun-related crimes rose by 50%, and the firearm-related homicide rate in 2022 was the highest since 1991.
title: Firearms and violent crime in Canada, 2022

quotes: ['"Canadian Level I air carriers flew 6.0 million passengers on scheduled and charter services in November" - "While this was up 8.6% from the same month in 2022, the number of passengers in November 2023 was 2.2% below the November 2019 level, before the COVID-19 pandemic" - "At 15.5 billion, the number of passenger-kilometres in November 2023 was above pre-pandemic levels (+1.4% from November 2019) for the second consecutive month" - "Capacity, at 19.0 billion available seat-kilometres, was on par with pre-pandemic levels for the first time" - "The passenger load factor was 81.9% in November 2023, compared with 80.8% in November 2019" - "Each passenger travelled an average of 2,584 kilometres in November 2023, up 3.6% from the same month in 2019" - "Operating revenue earned by Level I air carriers totalled $2.0 billion in November 2023, 14.6% higher than in the same month of 2019" - "This was the 12th consecutive month of operating revenue exceeding pre-pandemic levels."']
summary: In November 2023, Canadian Level I air carriers transported 6.0 million passengers, an 8.6% increase from 2022 but 2.2% below November 2019 levels. Passenger-kilometres reached 15.5 billion, surpassing pre-pandemic figures by 1.4%, with available seat-kilometres at 19.0 billion matching pre-pandemic capacity. The load factor was 81.9%, slightly higher than the 80.8% in November 2019. Passengers traveled an average of 2,584 kilometres, a 3.6% increase from 2019. Flying hours were down by 5.3% compared to pre-pandemic levels. Operating revenue for air carriers hit $2.0 billion, marking a 14.6% rise from November 2019 and the 12th month of revenue exceeding pre-pandemic levels.
title: Monthly civil aviation statistics, November 2023

quotes: ['"In November, aircraft movements at Canada\'s major and select small airports totalled 447,863. This was an increase of 9.1% from November 2022 and the largest year-over-year gain since March 2023." - "The number of international movements between Canada and countries other than the United States was up 16.2% year over year in November, while movements to and from the United States increased 7.3%." - "Total domestic movements increased 5.8% from November 2022." - "Total aircraft movements in November stood at roughly 98% of the November 2019 level, the highest monthly recovery since the beginning of the COVID-19 pandemic." - "Other international traffic (outside the United States) rose 16.2% from November 2022 to 14,971 and was 8.9% higher than in November 2019." - "Transborder movements (to and from the United States) increased 7.3% year over year to 33,370 in November 2023 but were 11.0% below the November 2019 level." - "Total domestic movements (within Canada) were up 5.8% year over year to 252,976 in November 2023, with those from smaller carriers (Level IV to VI) rising 12.4%." - "London in Ontario (+3,428 movements) reported the largest year-over-year increase in November." - "Toronto/Lester B. Pearson International remained the busiest airport in Canada, with 31,013 movements."']
summary: In November 2023, Canada's major and select small airports saw a 9.1% increase in aircraft movements compared to November 2022, totaling 447,863. International movements excluding the US rose by 16.2%, while US-related traffic increased by 7.3%. Domestic movements within Canada grew by 5.8%. Overall, aircraft movements were at 98% of November 2019 levels, indicating a strong recovery from the pandemic. Itinerant movements climbed 6.4%, and local movements surged 15.2%. Most provinces and territories experienced traffic growth, with Ontario leading in activity. London, Ontario, saw the largest individual airport increase, while Toronto remained the busiest airport.
title: Aircraft movement statistics: Major and select small airports, November 2023

summary: In 2022, the repair and maintenance services subsector saw a 7.9% increase in operating revenues, reaching $36.9 billion, with a slight dip in profit margin to 9.1%. The automotive repair and maintenance industry group contributed 62.5% of this revenue, growing by 7.5% to $23.1 billion, despite a marginal decrease in profit margin to 8.7%. Non-automotive repair and maintenance generated $13.8 billion, maintaining a stable profit margin of 9.8%. Increased demand in 2023 is driven by supply chain issues affecting new vehicle availability, leading to more repairs and maintenance of existing vehicles and machinery.

quotes: ["'Operating revenue in the Canadian real estate agents and brokers industry fell by over one-fifth (-21.8%)", 'Higher borrowing costs dampened existing home sales through 2022', 'Ontario, which accounted for the largest share of operating revenue nationally (55.0%), fell 25.9% to $11.5 billion in 2022', 'Alberta was the only province to post an increase in operating revenue, growing 5.0% from 2021 to 2022', 'The operating profit margin decreased from 36.5% in 2021 to 31.3% in 2022', "Operating revenue in the real estate agents and brokers industry is expected to continue to decline in 2023'"]
summary: In 2022, the Canadian real estate agents and brokers industry saw a 21.8% decrease in operating revenue, dropping from $26.7 billion in 2021 to $20.9 billion. This decline was influenced by the Bank of Canada's interest rate hikes, which rose from 0.25% to 4.25%. Despite the downturn, revenues remained 34.5% higher than pre-pandemic levels in 2019. Ontario experienced a 25.9% revenue drop, while Alberta saw a 5.0% increase. Operating expenses fell by 15.4%, with subcontract expenses being the largest cost. The operating profit margin decreased from 36.5% to 31.3%. Challenges are expected to persist in 2023, with further declines anticipated due to ongoing weakness in home sales and rising borrowing costs.
title: Real estate agents and brokers, 2022

quotes: ["'In December, 4.5 million passengers passed through pre-board security screening at checkpoints operated at Canada's eight largest airports, an increase of 8.9% compared with the number of passengers during the challenging holiday travel period of December 2022", 'December 2023 traffic was 3.5% below the same month in 2019, ending a five-month run in which total passengers had surpassed pre-COVID-19 pandemic volumes', 'Domestic passenger traffic in December (-1.0%) was down compared with December 2022, marking the first year-over-year monthly decline for this sector in 2023', 'Transborder traffic to the United States (+15.0%) was up sharply from December 2022', 'Other international traffic (outside the United States) increased by 18.5% compared with the same month in 2022', 'The 1.5 million passengers screened for international flights in December 2023 was also higher (+6.8%) than the volume reported in December 2019, making it the only sector to surpass pre-pandemic volumes', "Six of Canada's eight largest airports reported increases in year-over-year screened passenger traffic, with Ottawa Macdonald Cartier International, Montréal-Trudeau International, and Toronto Pearson International reporting double-digit increases", "Only Montréal-Trudeau International reported a December 2023 passenger volume higher than that of December 2019 (+4.6%)'"]
summary: In December 2023, Canada's eight largest airports saw 4.5 million passengers, an 8.9% increase from December 2022 but 3.5% below December 2019. Domestic traffic declined by 1.0% year-over-year and was 8.5% lower than in 2019. Transborder traffic to the U.S. rose by 15.0%, yet remained below pre-pandemic levels. Other international traffic grew by 18.5% from 2022 and was 6.8% higher than in 2019. Six airports reported increases, with Montréal-Trudeau International exceeding December 2019 volumes by 4.6%, marking its ninth consecutive month of growth. Edmonton and Halifax saw declines compared to December 2022.
title: Screened passenger traffic at Canadian airports, December 2023

The revisions had minimal effect on employment estimates and unemployment rates in Canada, with changes in the unemployment rate not exceeding 0.1 percentage points. The national unemployment rate for December 2023 remained at 5.8% after the revision.
title: Labour Force Survey: Revisions, 2021 to 2023

quotes: ["'Average total income of farm families operating a single farm in Canada rose by almost one-fifth (+19.1%) compared with 2020 to $214,089 in 2021", 'Average net operating income was up 41.5% to $99,786 in 2021', 'In 2021, the Government of Canada increased AgriRecovery funding to support farmers facing difficulties caused by drought and wildfires', 'Average off-farm income rose by 4.7% to $114,303 in 2021', 'The average total income of farm families rose by 7.9% to $143,368 in the unincorporated sector in 2021, compared with a 28.9% increase to $365,484 in the incorporated sector', 'The average total income of farm families operating crop farms grew by over one-fifth (+21.9%) in 2021 to $245,898', 'Potato farm families once again had the highest average total income, at $436,475 per farm family', 'Fruit and tree nut farm families had the highest average off-farm income, at $144,488 per farm family', 'Nationally, farm families in Saskatchewan earned the highest average total income, at $271,945 per farm family', "Farm families in British Columbia posted the highest average off-farm income nationally at $136,761'"]
summary: In 2021, Canadian farm families' average total income rose by 19.1% to $214,089, with net operating income up 41.5% to $99,786, largely due to increased AgriRecovery funding. Off-farm income, which constitutes 53.4% of total income, increased by 4.7% to $114,303. Incorporated farm families saw a 28.9% income increase to $365,484, outpacing the unincorporated sector's 7.9% rise to $143,368. Crop farming families experienced a 21.9% income growth, with potato farms having the highest average income at $436,475. Regionally, Saskatchewan farm families had the highest average income at $271,945, while British Columbia families had the highest off-farm income at $136,761.
title: Total income of farm families, 2021

file_2: Fisheries, Oceans and the Canadian Coast Guard
quotes: ["'Canada's coastal population grew by 5.3% from 2016 to 5.5 million people in 2021", 'An additional 207,820 people lived in the southern coastal area of British Columbia in 2021 compared with five years earlier, the largest increase nationally', 'Over twice as many people were living within less than five metres above sea level on the Pacific Coast (318,225 people) compared with the Atlantic Coast (142,492)', 'In 2023, known areas of seagrass meadows extended across 1,651 km2 of coastal oceans, while salt marshes covered 3,602 km2 of coastal area', "In 2022, 14.6% of Canada's ocean and coastal areas were protected or conserved", 'The conserved area increased by nearly 44,000 km2 from 2021 to 844,059 km2, mainly because of the addition of the Eastern Canyons Conservation Area in the Scotian Shelf bioregion in the Atlantic Ocean', "In 2022, 37% of the mapped area of these ecosystems was conserved or protected'"]
summary: In 2021, 5.5 million Canadians lived within 10 km of the coast, with the Pacific Coast seeing the most growth. Coastal population increased by 5.3% since 2016, with significant growth in British Columbia and the Maritime provinces. Conversely, the Newfoundland ecoprovince experienced a population decline. Over 460,000 Canadians live less than five meters above sea level, posing risks due to rising sea levels. Enhanced mapping has identified 1,651 km² of seagrass and 3,602 km² of salt marshes, vital for coastline protection and carbon storage. As of 2022, 14.6% of Canada's marine areas are protected, with a goal to reach 25% by 2025 and 30% by 2030.
title: Census of Environment: A snapshot of Canada's growing coastal communities and their natural environment

summary: In November, Canadian payroll employment fell by 88,300 (-0.5%), largely due to a strike in Quebec's education sector. Excluding this, the decline was 25,300 (-0.1%). Retail trade employment continued to drop for the third month, with a cumulative loss of 12,500 (-0.6%) since September. Wholesale trade also declined by 5,000 (-0.6%), and accommodation and food services decreased by 5,600 (-0.4%). However, health care and social assistance grew by 6,700 (+0.3%), and public administration increased by 3,900 (+0.3%). Average weekly earnings rose by 0.6% to $1,228. Job vacancies edged up to 653,000, with notable increases in accommodation and food services, retail trade, and manufacturing. Ontario saw a significant rise in job vacancies, up by 21,200 (+9.8%).
title: Payroll employment, earnings and hours, and job vacancies, November 2023

quotes: ["'Overall, 1 in 10 youth report being 2SLGBTQ+", 'Lower income among 2SLGBTQ+ individuals despite higher educational attainment', "Among 2SLGBTQ+ people, 3 in 10 consider their mental health to be fair or poor'"]
summary: Statistics Canada's data from the 2019-2021 Canadian Community Health Survey reveals that 4.4% of Canadians aged 15 and older identify as 2SLGBTQ+. Youth aged 15-24 are the most likely to identify as such, with 10.5% reporting they belong to this group. Despite higher educational attainment, 2SLGBTQ+ individuals have lower incomes, with 18.4% in the bottom income quintile. Mental health disparities are significant, with 29.7% of 2SLGBTQ+ people rating their mental health as fair or poor, compared to 9.1% of non-2SLGBTQ+ individuals. Transgender or non-binary individuals report even higher rates of fair or poor mental health at 54.7%.
title: Socioeconomic profile of the 2SLGBTQ+ population aged 15 years and older, 2019 to 2021

summary: In 2022, Canadian tourism industries invested $25.4 billion in non-residential capital assets, comprising 6.2% of the country's total non-residential investment, a decrease from 6.6% in 2021. Investment declines were notable in urban transit systems and passenger car rentals. The private sector's share of tourism investment increased for the first time since 2016, accounting for 46.2% of the total, led by Ontario with $4.9 billion. Public sector investment was dominated by provincial, territorial, and Indigenous general governments, with Ontario contributing 58.3% to the sector's investment in the province. Overall, capital investment by tourism industries fell by 2.7% in real terms in 2022.
title: Tourism Investment Module, 2022

file_2: Employment, Future Workforce Development and Disability Inclusion
quotes: ["'Working from home and public transit use in Canada, 2016 to 2023", "Risks to Canada's corporate sector as interest rates rise", 'The short-term labour market outcomes of blended visa office-referred refugees', 'Earnings of one-step and two-step economic immigrants: Comparisons from the arrival year', "Transition to permanent residency and retention of temporary foreign workers in accommodation and food services and food manufacturing'"]
summary: The shift to remote work has led to a significant decline in public transit use in Canada, with urban commuters dropping from 14.8% in 2016 to 11.8% in 2023. Canadian corporate debt has risen to 160% of GDP, posing risks of insolvency and economic slowdown. Blended Visa Office-Referred refugees show better early employment outcomes than government-assisted refugees but lag behind privately sponsored ones. Two-step economic immigrants earn more than one-step immigrants from arrival, suggesting better skill-market fit. Low-skilled foreign workers in accommodation, food services, and food manufacturing are less likely to obtain permanent residency compared to high-skilled workers.
title: Economic and Social Reports, January 2024

quotes: ["'29% of TFWs with lower-skill occupations who entered the accommodation and food services industry from 2010 to 2014 became permanent residents by their fifth year working in the industry", 'The rates were higher for TFWs with higher-skill occupations (45%) and study permit holders (49%)', 'five years after immigration, nearly 40% of TFWs with lower-skill occupations who became permanent residents from 2011 to 2015 stayed in the accommodation and food services industry', 'the rate was higher among TFWs with higher-skill occupations (52%) but lower for study permit holders (16%)', 'TFWs with lower-skill occupations who arrived in Canada from 2010 to 2014 displayed lower cumulative rates of transition to permanent residency (39%) than TFWs with higher-skill occupations (48%)', 'the retention rate decreased from 73% in the year of immigration to 36% five years later', "the percentage of TFWs who stayed in the industry decreased from 69% for the 2006-to-2010 landing cohort to 57% for the 2016-to-2019 landing cohort'"]
summary: In Canada, TFWs with lower-skill occupations in the accommodation and food services industry have a lower rate of transition to permanent residency (29%) compared to those with higher-skill occupations (45%) and study permit holders (49%). Despite this, they represent a larger number of immigrants due to their greater numbers. Post-immigration, 40% of these TFWs remain in the industry after five years, less than higher-skill TFWs (52%) but more than study permit holders (16%). In the food manufacturing industry, TFWs with lower-skill occupations show a declining retention rate, dropping from 73% to 36% over five years post-immigration. Each new cohort of TFWs sees a lower percentage remaining in the industry one year after becoming permanent residents, from 69% for the 2006-2010 cohort to 57% for the 2016-2019 cohort.
title: Transition to permanent residency and retention of temporary foreign workers in accommodation and food services and food manufacturing

quotes: ['"In Quebec, the proportion of immigrants who can conduct a conversation in French only or along with English more than doubled, from 38.4% in 1951 to 80.5% in 2021." \' "In Canada outside Quebec, just over 1 in 20 immigrants (5.5%) could have a conversation in French only or along with English in 2021, down slightly from 2001 (6.6%)." \' "In Quebec, 54.3% of immigrants had French as their first official language spoken in 2021, while one-quarter (25.2%) had English." \' "In 2021, 102,000 immigrants had French as their first official language spoken in Canada outside Quebec, the majority of whom lived in Ontario (66,000), Alberta (13,000) and British Columbia (12,000)." \' "The proportion of French-speaking immigrants to Canada who settled outside Quebec increased; among recent immigrants, it rose from 11.0% in 2006 to 17.9% in 2021."']
summary: In 2021, immigrants made up 23% of Canada's population, with 93.6% able to converse in English or French, continuing a historical trend. In Quebec, 80.5% of immigrants could speak French, a significant increase from 38.4% in 1951. Conversely, English-only speaking immigrants in Quebec declined from 56.8% in 1951 to 15.4% in 2021. In the rest of Canada, 5.5% of immigrants spoke French in 2021, a slight decrease from 2001. Over half of Quebec's immigrants in 2021 had French as their first official language, a reversal from 1971. Outside Quebec, French-speaking immigrants surpassed 100,000 in 2021, with a growing proportion of recent immigrants speaking French.
title: New historical data tables on immigration and official languages
